Name: Alan Mak
Message: See below for an update on what actions I'll be taking as a result of the Grenfell Tower fire last week: Like all of you, I was shocked by the devastation and horror of the Grenfell Tower fire last week. My thoughts and prayers are with all those who lost loved ones or suffered as a result of the fire. My gratitude also goes to our brave firefighters and emergency services who excelled in the most difficult of circumstances. As we come to terms with the aftermath of the fire, I wanted to let you know what I‚Äôll be doing as your local MP to ensure that this tragedy is not repeated elsewhere in the UK, particularly in Havant. It is right that this process starts with the independent public inquiry that has been ordered by the Prime Minister to investigate the causes of the fire. If this judge-led investigation finds that our fire safety rules surrounding tall buildings need to be strengthened, then I‚Äôll support appropriate action in Parliament. I have already met the Housing &...

Name: Alan Mak
Message: I thought I‚Äôd update you on the work I have been doing to seek reassurances for residents living in high rise flats in the Havant constituency. Below is the full letter I have received from The Guinness Partnership, who own 168 flats in three high rise buildings in Leigh Park. While I‚Äôm thankful that none of the buildings have the same type of cladding as used at Grenfell Tower in London, I welcome the review by Guinness into fire safety and I have asked for a copy of their final report to be sent to me. Nationally, I fully support the announcement yesterday by the Government of a new independent expert advisory panel to advise on any immediate measures that can be put in place to make buildings safe. I have already met the Fire Minister and the Housing & Planning Minister about Grenfell and the actions we can take going forward. This expert panel, which is separate to the Public Inquiry, will look at any immediate action that is required so the public can be confident everything...

Name: Albert Owen
Message: Began today in London before travelling home-my thoughts remains with the families and residents of Grenfell Tower in north Kensington.

Name: Alex Chalk
Message: Following the dreadful tragedy at Grenfell Tower in London I have today spoken to Gloucestershire's Chief Fire Officer to seek urgent reassurance about all high-rise buildings in Cheltenham. I am advised that fire crews have now visited all our relevant buildings. They have carried out further risk assessments and provided reassurance to local residents. I am assured that there is no cause for concern and that the buildings are safe. Government Ministers also gave instructions that checks should be carried out on every high rise with similar cladding to that at Grenfell Tower. None are affected in Gloucestershire. Meanwhile, I attended a briefing in Parliament from ministers this afternoon, and the Prime Minister has ordered a full public inquiry. No stone must be left unturned in getting to the bottom of what happened in Grenfell Tower. My thoughts are with all those affected by this horrific incident.

Name: Alex Chalk
Message: Grenfell Tower update: implications for Cheltenham This morning I was in the House of Commons to hear the PM's further statement about the appalling Grenfell Tower tragedy. In that statement she indicated that other high rise blocks in the UK have been found to be using cladding, samples of which have been shown to be 'combustible'. More results will be made public in the next 48 hours. This was very concerning. My immediate thought, obviously, was for residents in Cheltenham. So, having spoken further to the county's Chief Fire Officer today, I can provide the following update: Cheltenham has zero high-rise buildings with similar cladding to Grenfell Tower. However, there are three medium-rise buildings that have been confirmed to use a different type of cladding, known as 'Rockwool'. I have indicated that core sampling and fire testing of this cladding must be carried out urgently. I am assured that arrangements are being made to do so. An expedited report will then be provided...

Name: Alex Cunningham
Message: "Thirteen Group own most of the social housing across Teesside. They paid for fire-retardant, non-toxic cladding for the balconies in Kennedy Gardens in Billingham in my constituency. ‚ÄúThey ended up with flammable toxic material now being removed. One thing paid for, and another dangerous alternative provided."

Name: Alison McGovern
Message: This week. It has been a busy one so far: catching up on Brexit, Syria, Yemen, the latest on school funding, free school meals, and in the middle of it all, asking the Prime Minister when she will publish Bishop James Jones' report on the experience of the Hillsborough families. Why does this matter? Because the Prime Minister herself asked Bishop James to report to her about the challenges faced by this amazing group of people who have dealt with the worst possible catastrophe, and then had to fight the state to be treated properly, and to see the truth come out. Presumably, she asked for this report because she thought there was something to learn. If so, those lessons are now urgent. I believe that there are still parts of the state that do not know how to treat people who are bereaved or who have survived catastrophe. And if we don't listen now, whether it is Grenfell tower, or New Ferry explosion, or any other horrific event, we need a Government that is prepared to work with...

Name: Alison Thewliss
Message: Following the tragic events at Grenfell Tower, I questioned the Secretary of State for Communities and Local Government on providing adequate resources to the fire service, as well as asking him to ensure that residents who are rehoused get the same terms or better in their tenancy agreements and that he takes into account good examples of building regulations and resilience planning in Scotland.

Name: Alison Thewliss
Message: The Scottish Parliament's Local Government and Communities Committee has produced an important report on residential fire safety, highlighting measures to increase fire prevention like unannounced fire safety inspections and national inventories of high rise buildings. These measures should be introduced across the UK to ensure another tragedy like Grenfell Tower does not occur again. https://sp-bpr-en-prod-cdnep.azureedge.net/published/LGC/2017/10/30/Building-Regulations-and-Fire-Safety-in-Scotland/LGCS052017R9.pdf

Name: Alison Thewliss
Message: Firefighters do an amazing job keeping us all safe - demonstrated by the efficient response to the fire in Sauchiehall Street yesterday. In the wake of the Grenfell tragedy, I asked the Secretary of State what steps the UK Government is taking to ensure that comprehensive fire prevention measures are in place for all buildings - whether they are owned, privately rented or socially rented.

Name: Andy Slaughter
Message: Which?, the consumer organisation, has published a comprehensive report into the safety of fridges and freezers being sold in the UK. Nearly half of the products tested are potentially unsafe, and Which? has named 250 products as Don't Buys. Which? is a fantastic organisation that has worked tirelessly to promote fire safety following the fire at Grenfell, but it is very sad that it is having to do this work with little support from the Government.

Name: Angela Eagle
Message: Yesterday, during an Urgent Question in Parliament about the use of cladding on residential buildings, I asked the Secretary of State for Housing whether he would ensure that there is sufficient enforcement of any new building regulations, in light of concerns raised in a report published by Dame Judith Hackitt. Her report into building safety regulations called for an overhaul of the construction industry to put safety above cutting costs. Her report highlighted concerns about increased privatisation of the building inspection regime leading to safety being compromised and a reduction in expertise within local authorities. This Government‚Äôs austerity policies have led to a reduction in the level of building safety inspectors and enforcement of building regulations. It is clear that the self-regulation of competitive industries, such as construction has not worked. It is therefore vital that the Government guarantees that there are adequate resources in place to inspect and enforce...

Name: Angela Rayner
Message: Tory Ministers in abrupt U-turn over fire safety in schools. I raised this issue last August about removing the need to fit sprinklers in new schools but Tories ignored us all including the London fire commissioner Ron Dobson who said changes could have ‚Äúpotentially devastating consequences‚Äù. I am glad the Tories are now looking at this again but it should never have been proposed, we now need to be vigilant and make sure we push for sprinklers to be fitted as a matter of course...https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2017/jun/24/government-u-turn-over-fire-safety-controls-for-new-schools

Name: Bridget Phillipson
Message: Today I visited the towers at Lakeside to discuss fire safety with members of the Lakeside Residents Association (LRA) following the devastating fire at Grenfell Tower in London last month. I was joined by staff members from Gentoo and Chris Lane, a Station Manager in Sunderland from Tyne and Wear Fire and Rescue Service (TWFRS). It was very helpful to speak to residents face to face and to hear their concerns about fire safety. I was pleased that they felt so reassured by the help and support that Gentoo and TWFRS have offered since the fire. I was also very impressed to witness the fire alarm system in one of the towers first hand. It‚Äôs clear that Gentoo have robust procedures in place to mitigate against the risk of fire, and that staff are doing everything they can to make residents feel safe. The fire at Grenfell Tower was a national tragedy that should never happen again. We all need to learn lessons from this terrible event, and I hope that the public and police inquiries...

Name: Bridget Phillipson
Message: I know this has been a really difficult year for many in our community. Brexit is still causing division and uncertainty, there are growing pressures on public services, and it‚Äôs becoming increasingly common to see people sleeping rough in our city centres again. Six months ago we were horrified by the appalling loss of life at Grenfell Tower and there have been several devastating terrorist attacks across the UK. It is easy to feel despondent and powerless when so much seems wrong in the world, but I want to take this opportunity to thank some of the people who are making a real difference to our lives every day. So here's to all the NHS staff who are working shifts to care for those in need, the extraordinarily brave police officers and firefighters who run towards danger to keep us safe time and time again, and those in the intelligence services, who have helped to foil more terror plots than we'll ever know about. Here's to the teachers, social workers, librarians and carers...

Name: Carol Monaghan
Message: Following the horrific event which has taken place at Grenfell Tower in London, I have been contacted by many constituents who are rightly concerned about the safety of similar multi-storey properties in Glasgow North West and across the city. Many of these blocks have either recently or are currently being refurbished. Having written to the Wheatley Group, which encompasses Glasgow Housing Association and Cube Housing Association among others, I have been assured that the materials used are different from the cladding system which was in place in Grenfell Tower and is manufactured with non-combustible materials designed to restrict the spread of fire. As part of their fire safety regime, fire stopping measures have been installed in their multi-storeys as well as sprinklers in many of the bin store areas. I understand that they have a programme in place to extend this to all properties. There are also daily patrols with local staff identifying health and safety issues. The...

Name: Carol Monaghan
Message: This is extremely welcome news to the residents of Glasgow Harbour who have been subject to many months of uncertainty and distress. After it was reported that Barratt Homes had agreed to meet the ¬£2 million cost of replacing similar cladding on an effected tower block in Croydon, as well as the employment of fire wardens, I wrote to Taylor Wimpey urging that similar steps be taken at Glasgow Harbour. I‚Äôm delighted to learn that they will indeed meet the direct costs of removing and replacing the cladding, as well as the associated fire safety measures which have been in place since this first came to light. I recognise that the issue is not yet concluded, but hopefully this positive news signals the beginning of the end.

Name: Caroline Lucas
Message: My heart goes out to all of those affected by the horrific fire and tragic loss of life at Grenfell Tower. With facts emerging about the speed the fire spread, witness accounts of alarms not sounding, no sprinklers in the building, and advance warnings of residents‚Äô safety fears being ignored, it‚Äôs our duty to prevent a similar tragedy ever occurring again, and to hold to account those responsible for the failures that make this potentially not just a tragedy but a crime. Here in Brighton & Hove, I've been told the council has already committed to a review of fire safety in its housing stock, which is reassuring. However, many residents are placed by the local authority in private rented property, so I think the review should be extended to include all properties, including those used for emergency and temporary accommodation - and I've stressed this again to them this week. For example, I recently wrote to the council about a home above a takeaway with an industrial vent that led...

Name: Chloe Smith
Message: Following the horrific fire at Grenfell Tower last week, I have received a letter from the Prime Minister, confirming the Government‚Äôs response to the disaster, which outlines how it plans to ensure that those directly affected are cared for and receive the support they need. The government is doing all it can to help people after this unimaginably awful fire. I want to express my grief for all involved. I have also contacted Norwich City Council promptly to seek reassurances that my constituents who live in tower blocks in Mile Cross and Heartsease are safely housed.

Name: Chris Davies
Message: Well the B&R Blog is Back! It has been a very interesting week since the 2017 General Election. What ever the reason and whatever the result - We are where we are!!! For all followers of politics you can find out what has been happening in Westminster from any news bulletin or newspaper but I hope to tell you in my blogs how it is behind the press reports for an active Member of Parliament. For an MP of two years standing it is a strange feeling coming back to Westminster to resume your duties as an MP. The route to London is the same, the Palace of Westminster looks the same, and the staff are the same. But you find that you are no longer the new boy and there are 80 something newbies and you have become part of the old guard. This week has been full of congratulations and commiserations - pleased to see so many colleagues back with several having now been made ministers. But also speaking to great friends and colleagues who have not returned to Westminster and some friends who...

Name: Chris Elmore
Message: The horror that has unfolded at Grenfell Tower in west London this week is incomprehensible, clearly the loss of life will continue to grow. When such heart break happens, it is incumbent on us all to stand with, support and find answers for such a tragic loss of life. I'm angry this morning that our Prime Minister has shown none of these characteristics, with one of her Ministers blaming security concerns. I find this excuse utterly insulting. London Mayor, Sadiq Khan and the Leader of the Oppositon Jeremy Corbyn, both attended speaking to residents affected, those who had lost loved ones and our emergency services who as ever are the heroes of our society. This isn't about politics, Labour or Conservative, it's about a level of common humanity and empathy with those facing loss. Our Prime Minister has failed on all counts. http://www.mirror.co.uk/news/politics/tory-minister-claims-security-concerns-10631543#ICID=sharebar_twitter

Name: Chris Elmore
Message: Yesterday I spoke in the Grenfell Tower debate to again highlight the risk of flammable insulation. I'm concerned that the Government are not focusing on the role that insulation could have played in the fire. The Government has further confirmed to me that they're not testing insulation around tower blocks. I have now written to Sir Martin Moore-Bick, Chair of the inquiry, to ask him to consider this.

Name: Chris Elmore
Message: Just a quick update on my campaign for safer insulation. Just before the terms of reference were announced, I received a reply from Sir Martin Moore-Bick, Chair of the Grenfell Inquiry. Sir Martin tells me that he is confident that insulation will be considered in the forthcoming inquiry. I will be following the investigation carefully as public hearings soon begin. No stone can be left unturned.

Name: Chris Elmore
Message: It's been great to get back to Parliament this week to start campaigning on the issues which are important to you - my constituents. To complete the list of issues I've highlighted this week which I'll be focusing on is my work on flammable insulation. It's vitally important that any lessons taken from Grenfell are heeded when constructing social housing (and indeed private housing) across the UK:

Name: Chris Elmore
Message: Since the Grenfell fire, I have sought to highlight the vital issue of flammable insulation. Earlier this week I called on the UK Government to investigate this issue as an essential part of the ongoing work to replace flammable cladding on high rise buildings.

Name: Chris Green
Message: My latest column for the Leigh Observer is below. You can read my next one in this week's paper, which is out now. I would like to wish you all a very happy New Year. As we begin 2018, it is natural to look back on the year we have had ‚Äì and what a year of ups and downs 2017 has been. I think when we look back on 2017 in years to come, we will remember the horrific terror attacks which shook our country ‚Äì including one right on our doorsteps at Manchester Arena. We will never forget the images we saw and the stories we read of these awful attacks and we will never forget the families who lost children and parents. It is difficult to imagine that they will have just spent their first Christmas without their loved ones. At least nine terror attacks have been foiled by police and security services in our country this year. It is right that the government has increased the police‚Äôs counter terrorism budget by 7 percent, with a ¬£50 million increase taking it to at least ¬£757 million....

Message: In light of the Grenfell Tower tragedy it was a priority of mine to contact all housing associations in ‚ÄòDaventry‚Äô to ensure that nothing similar could ever happen here. Everyone has the right to feel safe and secure in their home. You can see these responses on my website or by clicking the link below. Name: Chris Philp
Message: The Government has successfully persuaded the housing development company Barratt Developments to fund the recladding of Citiscape. The cladding of Citiscape, two blocks of flats on the corner of Frith and Drummond Road, was deemed to be a fire safety risk following the Grenfell tragedy ‚Äì with residents told that they would have to pay for the recladding. The cost of recladding an improving fire safety were expected to cost leaseholders between ¬£5,000 to ¬£6,000 per flat. The two tower blocks, which are ten and six storeys tall respectively contain 97 flats, with the exterior covered in a cladding material deemed unsafe following the Grenfell tragedy. Sajid Javid, the Secretary of State for Housing, Communities and Local Government, announced the decision via Twitter, stating: ‚ÄúDelighted Barratt Developments have told residents of the #Citiscape flats they will cover fire safety and cladding costs. This is the right thing to do and I want to see others follow their lead to protect...

Name: Christopher Pincher
Message: Many residents have written to me about the Grenfell Tower disaster. Here is my open response: I would first like to express my sincerest sympathies for those affected by the tragedy at Grenfell. My thoughts are with those who have lost loved ones, friends and homes. It is a sobering experience to drive by and see the ruins of the tower. I would also like to pay tribute to our fantastic emergency services who have worked so hard during such difficult circumstances. Since the fire on 15th June I have received messages of concern from constituents regarding fire safety, especially at Tamworth‚Äôs own local authority high rises on Lichfield Street. Because of the terrible events in West London, I have contacted Councillor Michelle Thurgood, portfolio folder for Housing Services at #Tamworth Borough Council for further information on the Lichfield Street flats, although I am aware that both Anthony Goodwin, Chief Executive of Tamworth Borough Council and the Head of Landlord services...

Name: Chuka Umunna
Message: PLEASE SHARE: As many of you will have seen, there has been a truly devastating fire in the Grenfell Tower block in Kensington. Hundreds of people and families are now homeless and have lost their belongings. There are four sites taking collections and donations for those affected in Streatham. The Hyderi Islamic Centre, South London Islamic Centre, and Brixton Mosque have asked that any donations be dropped off between 8pm and midnight. The Brixton Soup Kitchen will be open during working hours and in the early evening. Please give what you can, clothes, food, or drink. It will make a big, big difference.

Name: Chuka Umunna
Message: The locations in Streatham and Brixton collecting donations for the Grenfell Fire Appeal: Hyderi Islamic Centre, 26 Estreham Road, SW16 EPQ South London Islamic Centre, 8 Mitcham Lane, SW16 6NN Brixton Soup Kitchen, 297-299 Coldharbour Lane, SW9 8RP Brixton Mosque, 1 Gresham Road, SW9 7PH Please give what you can spare, especially toiletries.

Name: Claire Perry
Message: Like everyone across the country, I have been deeply saddened by the tragedy which occurred at Grenfell Tower in London, and can only begin to imagine how terrifying this has been for everyone concerned, including the Emergency Services. Although we do not have any similar scale buildings in the Devizes Constituency, I am aware that many Housing Association tenants and members of the Armed Forces live in flats, including many elderly and vulnerable people. There are also a number of older houses both Service Family Accommodation and Housing Association homes, which I appreciate are regularly being monitored and appraised for updating and maintenance issues. I have written to all the Housing Associations and also to the Ministry of Defence seeking confirmation that their Fire Prevention measures are frequently reviewed, and that all tenants are regularly updated regarding what action to take in the event of a fire. I have received some responses, which I thought you may find...

Name: Clive Lewis
Message: I'm pleased everyone involved has acted quickly to review fire risk across the city since the tragedy at Grenfell Tower in London. To date, in Norwich, six accommodation blocks have been found which have external cladding that has failed fire safety tests. I'm informed that one of the medium rise blocks belongs to Broadland Housing Association whilst the other five are privately owned. I‚Äôve been told tenants in all six buildings have now been contacted. The building company which constructed the buildings has also been informed. Consequently Norfolk's Fire service has advised extra fire safety measures (moving cars from underneath the blocks, 24/7 wardens and immediate evacuation in case of fire) which will mitigate risks. I‚Äôm told these measures will stay in place until further guidance is received. All residents and tenants in the affected buildings have been notified of the changes. I'm told the Fire Service are offering home safety visits. Norwich City Council and other...

Name: Clive Lewis
Message: I recently spoke in parliament about the need to make sure our local authorities, schools, fire and other services are properly funded in order to keep everyone safe and avoid another tragedy like Grenfell Towers. Schools in Norwich are suffering particularly badly from Government cuts and are threatened with the worst settlement in Norfolk under the proposed funding formula, although we are waiting to find out whether and how that will ever be implemented. I asked the minister to tell us whether any central funding will be made available for essential safety work, so that those schools do not face yet more unfunded costs from the Government. I also discuss how local authorities are being subjected to changes in funding and changes to their ways of working which could result in some councils making compromises on safety measures. Notably, I talk about the the Government‚Äôs mandatory 1% rent reduction, which reduces Norwich City Council's ability to repair and improve its ageing...

Name: Clive Lewis
Message: The public inquiry into the terrible fire at Grenfell Tower fire starts today. Since the fire, I‚Äôve taken a lot of action locally and in Parliament on the issues that have come up since. This is an update on what I‚Äôve done and am continuing to do. Immediately following the Grenfell fire, I swiftly got in contact with the key organisations in Norwich to seek assurances about the fire safety of any cladding in the city. The City Council informed me they were carrying out full risk assessments of each block, in addition to the daily safety checks conducted by wardens. I have been in regular correspondence with all organisations since about the issue. When it was announced that the cladding on Geoffrey Watling Way had failed its fire safety test I came back from Parliament to meet with Broadland Housing, Taylor Wimpey, and the Norfolk Fire Service on site. The Fire Service informed me they were making changes to increase fire safety such as moving cars from underneath the tower blocks,...

Name: Clive Lewis
Message: It was a pleasure to meet with some of Shelter's hardworking staff in Norwich on Friday to discuss the Fitness for Human Habitation Bill, and some of the other housing/homelessness issues which affect our city. The Fitness for Human Habitation Bill is a Private Members' Bill, sponsored by The Labour Party's Karen Buck, which comes before parliament on Friday. It seeks to make sure homes are fit for human habitation at the start of a tenancy and all the way throughout. This means that if a landlord is failing to take action over poor conditions in a property, the renter has the right to take them to court. The Grenfell Tower fire is a harrowing example of the consequences of neglecting tenant‚Äôs voices and not addressing concerns: legislation like this will be a step towards making sure such a tragedy will never happen again. Since my meeting with Shelter and me recording this video, the Government have confirmed they will be supporting the Bill. Committing to back an opposition bill...

Message: Over the summer Conor met with the Dorset and Wiltshire Chief Fire Officer at his invitation to be briefed on the local response to Grenfell Tower fire and the safety tests that have been undertaken in Bournemouth and Poole. He was also briefed on the working of the merger of Dorset and Wiltshire Fire Services as well as talking about future plans and challenges they have. At the end of the meeting Ben presented Conor with the shield of the new fire service.

Name: Conor McGinn
Message: Merseyside Fire and Rescue Service does a vital job protecting our communities in St Helens and across the region. But new figures uncovered by the Fire Brigades Union show that this Tory Government is planning to slash budgets for fire services ‚Äì with a 12 per cent cut expected for Merseyside in the four years up to 2020. These dangerous cuts, which will leave our firefighters with fewer resources, come on top of more than 11,000 firefighter job cuts since 2010. The terrible tragedy of Grenfell Tower last year underlined the importance of a fully funded fire and rescue service, but the new cuts will run down capabilities and damage morale. I‚Äôm backing the Fire Brigades Union in calling on the Government to urgently reverse these cuts and protect Merseyside Fire and Rescue Service. https://www.fbu.org.uk/SOFS

Name: Corri Wilson
Message: 1993!?! Sadly, all these years later and people still haven't woken up, in fact we are on a slippery slope backwards.....

Name: Dame Caroline Spelman
Message: I was shocked and saddened to learn of the massive blaze which engulfed Grenfell Tower in London in the early hours of yesterday morning and which has led to a significant loss of life. At this time our thoughts and prayers must be with the victims, their families and loved ones, and with the emergency services who responded so rapidly and so courageously to this incident. In the past 24 hours I have been contacted by local residents who have expressed their concerns about the high rise blocks in our borough which have undergone renovation in recent years. I have received assurances from Solihull Community Housing and the local authority that they work closely with the fire service, carry out regular risk assessments and are 'extremely aware' of what they as building managers need to do to ensure the safety of local residents at all times in case of a fire. I understand that more detailed information from SCH will be coming forward to local residents and I would urge any concerned...

Name: Dame Caroline Spelman
Message: Earlier today Councillor Ken Hawkins, Solihull Council Cabinet Member for Housing, and I visited some of the tower blocks in Chelmsley Wood to inspect the condition of cladding. Following regular correspondence with the local council and Solihull Community Housing as well as a meeting today with them, I have been advised that all of the necessary checks have been carried out to ensure that strictest fire regulations are met in all blocks and that the materials used to clad the facade of the building are not the same as those used in the case of Grenfell Tower in London. Further, that SCH's neighbourhood officers have been out visiting local residents and distributing literature to reassure tenants of the efforts being taken to ensure their safety.

Name: Dame Caroline Spelman
Message: Assurances sought from SMBC after Grenfell Tower blaze #Solihull #SCH https://www.carolinespelman.com/news/assurances-sought-smbc-after-grenfell-tower-blaze

Name: Damian Collins
Message: The Tragedy at Grenfell Tower The Grenfell Tower fire in North Kensington in London will surely been seen as one of the greatest civil disasters in this country since the Second World War. Alongside other disasters like Hillsborough and Aberfan, it was tragic both for the large loss and life, and because it was avoidable. A full public inquiry will establish the exact cause of the fire, but we know that there have been warnings about the risk of fire in tower blocks like these, the need for sprinklers systems, and concerns raised about certain types of building cladding that may be more vulnerable to fire. It is not enough however to say that lessons will be learnt and that the appropriate fire safety measures will be retrofitted into other blocks that may have a similar risk to Grenfell tower. What is required is a much bigger reform of the provision and management of social housing in this country. As I have written in this column before, there are too many people in poor quality...

Name: Dan Jarvis
Message: My thoughts today are with all those affected by the devastating fire at Grenfell Tower in West London. My heartfelt condolences go to those who have lost family and friends and particularly to those still waiting to hear whether their loved ones are safe. As a father and husband I can hardly bear to think about some of the decisions that people had to make and the heartache many must now be feeling. So many more lives would have been lost had it not been for the professionalism and bravery of our firefighters. Our emergency services have once again done our country proud. There seems to be no end to the horrific circumstances we ask them to face or the courage they show. But now we need to ask how preventable this one was. It goes without saying that all those affected deserve a number of answers. Not least, why have four year old recommendations on the installation of sprinklers, the overhauling of building regulations, and the delivery of better fire advice to residents not been...

Name: David Davies
Message: Your MP Writes: David Davies Monmouth MP via South Wales Argus FOLLOWING the terrible Grenfell Tower tragedy in London, we once again saw the incredible bravery of our firefighters and the overwhelming acts of public generosity. Bron Afon Community Housing responded very quickly to local concerns about their own high-rise blocks in the Cwmbran area with a full statement about how they approach fire safety. As an MP, I have sometimes had to cross swords with housing associations but I have every confidence in Bron Afon‚Äôs commitment to putting the safety of tenants before profits and I thank them for providing such important reassurances. I am extremely grateful to the electors of Monmouth for returning me with a slightly bigger vote share, although the overall result nationally was by no means a triumph for the Conservatives. However, the Conservative Party won more seats than any other party and has every right to form a government. Governments are formed on the basis of who can...

Message: I was just interviewed on BBC Radio 4's Today programme about the Grenfell Tower tragedy. Let's call it what it is - this is corporate manslaughter and people must be held to account. This is what I said in full:

Those responsible must be held to account in the dock in front of a judge and jury. If the preventable death of people burning to death in their homes is not a matter for the state, then what is? https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2017/jun/15/crime-grenfell-tower-burning-homes-police-fire

I will fight for justice for the victims and families, and I will not rest until those to blame are held to account. https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2017/jun/15/crime-grenfell-tower-burning-homes-police-fire?CMP=Share_iOSApp_Other

Name: David Lammy
Message: Khadija Saye - a wonderful emerging artist on the cusp of recognition. Her moment to shine had come. Rest in peace. https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2017/jun/17/khadija-saye-artist-was-on-cusp-of-recognition-when-she-died-in-grenfell

Name: David Lammy
Message: This morning I have written to the Commissioner of the Metropolitan Police Service Cressida Dick regarding the Grenfell Tower criminal investigation. We need answers and we need justice. The public need to know that the criminal investigation has all of the resources it needs and is being worked on by the very best officers. The public need to know that all companies, contractors and subcontractors involved in Greenfell Tower will be investigated by the police. And the public need to know that the public inquiry will not impede this criminal investigation. We need justice under law in court, we need those culpable to be held responsible before a judge and jury.

Name: David Lammy
Message: I have been in Kensington and Latimer Rd tonight meeting Grenfell survivors and local residents with local MP Emma Dent Coad. Community grieving but strong. Hurting but united. Thank for your kind messages in recent days. I will not rest until the victims and families of Grenfell get their justice. Solidarity.

Message: Rich, powerful organisations get away with crimes. In the House of Commons this morning I asked the PM why we haven't heard anything about the Grenfell criminal investigation. And I will keep asking until we get answers.

Name: David Lammy
Message: My question to the PM this morning on Grenfell. Rich, powerful people get away with crimes. We need to see progress in the criminal investigation. https://twitter.com/BBCParliament/status/877886815918841857

Name: David Lammy
Message: Grenfell Tower: Have we learnt nothing from Hillsborough? The rich and the powerful will do all they can to obfuscate, delay and cover up. The Government and establishment are pivoting to the cladding as a national problem. Correct, but that doesn't change anything when it comes to Grenfell. Yes, we are uncovering a national scandal. But that doesn't mean that Grenfell is not a crime, or that it should be brushed under the carpet, although that would be an ideal outcome for many rich, powerful organisations. It feels like the Government and establishment are rallying round to point to all the other examples of cladding on buildings. Let me remind you of a few things: Grenfell victims tried to raise these issues. Fire alarms didn't work. People were told to stay in their homes as their homes burned. We have corporate manslaughter on a huge scale. Yes, let's have a debate about social housing. Bring it on. But do not allow those in power to silence Grenfell. We still haven't heard...

Name: David Lammy
Message: Grenfell Tower - the death toll, suspicion of a cover-up and a community that has lost all faith in authority: Almost 2 weeks on from the fire and having spent time with some of the victims in recent days it is difficult to describe the pain people are going through holding out hope for loved ones that they know deep down will not be found alive. Trust is at rock bottom in the community, and the failure to provide updates about the true number of people who died and survived in Grenfell is driving a wedge between the authorities and the people they are elected to serve. Residents saw many people jumping out of windows during the fire, and survivors saw bodies piled up in the stairwells. Survivors know that huge numbers of their neighbours have not survived, and they simply cannot believe that the official death toll has not risen. Speaking to people on the ground there is huge suspicion that there is a cover-up underway, with the authorities withholding information in an attempt to...

Name: David Lammy
Message: Last night I was on Newsnight talking about Grenfell. I will stand alongside the community and all those who want answers about many people died in Grenfell Tower. A death toll of 79 does not accord with what survivors are saying, and we need to listen to them and act on their concerns. What are the authorities doing to come up with an estimation of how many people were in Grenfell? Are they speaking to the DWP, local schools, local doctors, phone companies, the local council tax office etc to get an estimation of how many people were in Grenfell that night? Not good enough. https://twitter.com/BBCNewsnight/status/879458704378044416

Name: David Lammy
Message: Delighted to have been nominated by MPs from across Parliament to be Chair of Communities and Local Government Select Committee. Grenfell, social housing and adult social care in particular are hugely important issues that require urgent attention. Here is my election statement to MPs in full:

Name: David Lammy
Message: My response to Grenfell Tower public inquiry consultation 1. Two-stage inquiry required 2. Advisory panel drawn from families and community

Name: David Lammy
Message: My response to the Grenfell Tower public inquiry consultation - we need a two-stage inquiry & Sir Martin Moore-Bick should appoint advisory panel. Public inquiry must examine specific circumstances and causes of the Grenfell Tower fire, but also the systemic failure at national and local level in the provision, administration and management of social housing. A failure to learn lessons would be a grave injustice both to those who died and also in putting other lives at risk. I have experienced first-hand the grief, anger and frustration of the Grenfell survivors, victims‚Äô families and the community in North Kensington. Sir Martin Moore-Bick must leave no stone unturned in identifying each and every individual & organisation who must bear responsibility and be held to account for this tragedy and its aftermath. https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2017/jul/26/david-lammy-grenfell-inquiry-martin-moore-bick

Name: David Lammy
Message: GRENFELL PUBLIC INQUIRY TERMS OF REFERENCE: The fight for justice for victims and their families is the most important aspect of the inquiry. It is right that the Grenfell inquiry looks into actions of Kensington and Chelsea Council before the fire, regulations and reaction of central & local Government but I am deeply disappointed that the narrow terms of reference ignore issue of the provision and management of social housing in the UK. What happened at Grenfell is evidence of systemic failure at a national and local level when it comes to social housing in this country. The decision to duck these important issues and fail to learn the broader lessons of Grenfell represents a grave injustice to those who died.

Name: David Lammy
Message: Scope of Grenfell Tower public inquiry should include provision and management of social housing in this country. As I have said, the decision to duck these broader national issues as part of the inquiry represents a grave injustice to those who died. https://labourlist.org/2017/08/jeremy-corbyn-pm-must-rethink-inquiry-into-grenfell-tower-blaze/

Message: This grotesque situation further demonstrates that RBKC are truly unfit for purpose and are failing Grenfell survivors. Name: David Lammy
Message: My statement on the Grenfell public inquiry: The first thing that Sir Martin Moore-Bick has to do is gain the trust of the community. The Grenfell public inquiry is not a trial ‚Äì the families must come first and it is his job to hold powerful organisations to account on their behalf. For that reason, and for justice to be done and for it be seen to be done, Sir Martin Moore-Bick has to walk alongside the Grenfell families, he has to be on their side and he has to be absolutely fearless when it comes to what went on within the local authority, within the tenant management association and within the various contractors and subcontractors. In my view the public inquiry terms of reference should have included the wider context of the provision and management of social housing in this country, and I made my views clear to Sir Martin Moore-Bick during the consultation period. I also believe that a panel of advisors or another form of community representation would have been an important...

Name: David Lammy
Message: hroughout the Grenfell inquiry process it is important to remember that the inquiry‚Äôs job is to hold those in power to account on behalf of those who lost their lives, their families and the survivors with fierce impartiality and without fear or favour. I was in North Kensington earlier today. As I said on the Today programme this morning, RBKC are treating Grenfell survivors as consumers, not human beings. It is transactional and about numbers, not about what people need. It is also important to remember that almost 6 months on from Grenfell the Government's promises lie in tatters.Half of Grenfell families are still in hotel rooms, 4/5 will not have a permanent home by Christmas. The 3 week rehousing promise has become 1 year. They have been failed again and again by the state. It is nothing short of a disgrace that only one in five households have been found permanent homes six months on from the fire and it becomes clearer every day that the Government should have sent in...

Name: David Lammy
Message: My friend Khadija Saye was a hugely talented emerging artist with so much to offer the world whose life was tragically cut short 6 months ago. In politics I am meant to be objective, but I am totally committed to supporting the Grenfell families, speaking out on their behalf and getting the justice that they need and deserve. Today we remember those who lost their lives in Grenfell Tower, support the families and commit to fight for justice for all those who lived in Grenfell.

Name: David Lammy
Message: I have written about Grenfell Tower, what it said silently but so powerfully about the state of our nation and a broken social contract between the state and the individual. About what happens regeneration becomes gentrification and mixed communities cease to exist, About the state of social housing, the human cost of the creeping privatisation of services previously carried out by the state, the atrophy of local government in the face of budget cuts, together with rampant commercialisation and gentrification masquerading as regeneration. About a state that seems to have forgotten how to do civic. About the natural outcome of what David Cameron meant by ‚Äúbig society‚Äù, where philanthropy and charity were supposed to replace an active state. About a local authority retreating from its role at the heart of the community ‚Äì apart from ensuring the bins were collected and the streets were cleaned. About a national psyche has cast the ‚Äúsocial‚Äù in social housing as a dirty word, while the...

Message: "When it comes to housing, our national psyche has cast the ‚Äúsocial‚Äù in social housing as a dirty word, while the ‚Äúmarket‚Äù in the housing market has come to reign supreme". Name: David Lammy
Message: Only 3 of the nearly 300 tower blocks deemed unsafe have had new cladding installed. Govnt refusing to pay for urgent safety work. Totally unacceptable. On 3rd July Secretary of State said the Govnt will "take every precaution to avoid another tragedy in buildings with similar cladding". On 5th September the Govnt said: "If they [councils] are not able to pay for that themselves, we will work with them and put a financial support package in place" to pay for "steps needed to ensure public safety in terms of fire risk". On 5th September the Govnt said that "we will work with each of them [local authorities] to make sure that they have the funding they need if funding is preventing them from doing that work" [repairs to tower blocks to ensure fire safety]. On 9th October the Govnt said that "we will not allow financial difficulties to stand in the way of doing the essential work"....

Name: David Lammy
Message: "There is very likely no-one in this chamber who lives in a council tower block estate." This is about trust. Grenfell residents were failed by the state. The Government promised to pay for repairs to prevent another tragedy and now people living in hundreds of tower blocks are being failed too. What does this say about the Government's response to Grenfell, and the respect it has for those 72 people who died, when they are refusing to fund repairs to take dangerous cladding off tower blocks?

Name: David Lammy
Message: After Grenfell Sajid Javid said the Government would take every precaution to prevent another tower block fire, and promised to support councils who couldn't afford to pay for repairs. Yet there are still hundreds of tower blocks with dangerous, flammable cladding.

Name: David Lammy
Message: My question at Housing and Local Government Questions today - on 4 July 2017 the Secretary of State Sajid Javid said that the Government would take every precaution to prevent another Grenfell Tower. 41 councils have asked for funding for repairs to over 300 unsafe tower blocks with cladding that failed fire safety tests in the wake of Grenfell yet the Secretary of State has given ¬£817m back to the Treasury. Why can't he find the money?

Name: David Lammy
Message: A picture speaks a thousand words. Justice for Grenfell.

Name: David Lammy
Message: If we have an Inquiry that fails to represent the people in whose interests it is supposed to act then it has failed before it has even begun. The Government has lost sight of who the Grenfell Inquiry is for. It is for the people who were failed before the fire and have been failed since the fire. It is for the victims, the survivors and everyone who is grieving and carrying the burden of loss like a scar burned into their soul. If the Inquiry is not for these people then it ceases to be an Inquiry, it becomes a talking shop and an exercise in spin.

Name: David Lammy
Message: PM has backed down and said the Government will pay to take down cladding from tower blocks after almost a year of saying no. I can't believe I had to fight for this and I can't believe the Government refused for so long, but they did. Well done all UKLabour colleagues campaigning on this for months.

Name: David Lammy
Message: A betrayal and a whitewash. My response to the Hackitt Review and the decision to not ban flammable cladding: This review is a betrayal and a whitewash. It is unthinkable and unacceptable that so many people can die in a disaster like Grenfell and one year on flammable cladding has not been banned. I will continue to stand with the Grenfell families and will continue to call for an outright ban on any combustible materials. The Grenfell families and the public needed a review that was fearless in standing up to the industry on behalf of all those who lost their lives in Grenfell with recommendations that ensure that an atrocity like Grenfell can never happen again. ]] I simply fail to see how it is deemed appropriate for any combustible material to be used on any tower block in this country and I find it unfathomable that this review has not recommended an outright ban on combustible material.

Name: David Lammy
Message: Almost a year after Grenfell and I still fail to see why the Govnt did not send in Commissioners to take over woefully inadequate RBKC on day one. https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-london-44295397

Name: David Lidington
Message: I recently wrote to Vale of Aylesbury Housing Association about their fire precautions following the Grenfell Tragedy. Their response can be found below.

Name: Dawn Butler
Message: Yesterday evening I chaired a meeting with residents of the Watling Gardens tower blocks after a number of residents had expressed concerns regarding the new cladding and insulation which was being installed in their blocks. At the start of the meeting a representative from Rockwall, who are responsible for the insulation installed in the three tower blocks conducted a controlled demonstration of the Rockwall insulation. The representative from Rockwall explained that the material used is non-combustible and that no fire would be able to travel like seen in the tragic events at Grenfell. The representative showed the residents at the meeting that the material was non-combustible as they lit a blow torch, with a heat of 1,100 degrees, on the insulation for the duration of the meeting and it did not catch alight. I recorded some of the demonstration as you can see here:

Name: Dawn Butler
Message: Today I asked a Point of Order following the postponement of the publication of the findings in the Prime Minister's Race Audit. This is a disappointing development which suggests the government is not taking the issue of racial disparity within public services seriously. There is already a strong mistrust of the government which has been exacerbated by the shocking Grenfell fire tragedy, that is why the release of the report at this time is so important. The Prime Minister must immediately explain why the report will not be released this month as planned and provide assurances that the report will be published unamended in full. The Prime Minister said this report would not shy away from difficult truths but now the government appears to be doing just that. This audit must not be delayed simply to hide embarrassment for the government or because the Prime Minister doesn‚Äôt like the findings.

Name: Dawn Butler
Message: I am passionate in my belief that we must create a lasting memorial for this awful fire. Remembering this tragedy is upsetting but it is also essential that we never forget what happened and those who lost their lives that night, some whom may never be identified. That is why I recently called on the government to make the site of Grenfell Tower a memorial garden in perpetuity.

Name: Deidre Brock
Message: I attended a briefing from the council's housing team today about fire safety in tower blocks in the city, following the horrific fire at Grenfell Tower in London. You can arrange a free home fire safety visit, including fitting of a smoke alarm if required, here: http://www.firescotland.gov.uk/your-safety/for-householders/home-fire-safety-visit.aspx

Name: Derek Thomas
Message: Which? End Dangerous Products Campaign I welcome the latest Which? Magazine‚Äôs new campaign to ‚ÄòEnd Dangerous Products‚Äô in the home. According to their investigation, faulty white goods such as washing machines, tumble dryers and fridge freezers cause more than 60 house fires a week, a truly shocking statistic. Indeed a fridge freezer started the horrific and tragic Grenfell Tower fire, although it is not yet clear whether the manufacturer was at fault. I have been aware of the fire hazards that such household goods present for a while through a charity called Electricity Safety First which works to ensure that everyone in the UK understands the importance of electrical safety and that this remains a priority for consumers, trade and government. Over the past couple of years I have organised several Winter Wellbeing and Health events in the constituency when a team from Electricity Safety First has been on hand to offer sensible, down-to-earth advice about their electric appliances...

Name: Diane Abbott
Message: I have written to the Home Secretary to request a full immigration amnesty for survivors of the Grenfell Tower fire who do not have a regularised immigration status. Without a full immigration amnesty there will be survivors and relatives of survivors who are frightened to approach the authorities. There will be people who have died whom we will never know about, and too many people who need help whom will not receive it. If the welfare of the survivors is the government‚Äôs priority then surely it is a basic humanitarian measure to ensure that nothing deters them from seeking the support that should be theirs as a right. To access all the support they need without fear of deportation, any survivors or their family members concerned about their status must be given indefinite leave to remain.

Name: Diane Abbott
Message: The Grenfell focus should be on the people - recent piece by Diane Abbott MP Since the terrible fire that consumed Grenfell Tower in North Kensington there has been much discussion about the cladding and details of the architecture. But we need to keep focussing on the people. This week I organised a meeting in Parliament for survivors of the tragic fire. Alongside me were my colleagues the local Member of Parliament Emma Coad Dent, Labours Shadow Justice Secretary, Richard Burgon MP and David Lammy MP. Over one hundred and fifty people attended. There were: solicitors; legal advisors; support groups; families of survivors and dozens of survivors themselves. I heard some incredibly tragic stories including a young woman and her daughter who had been on the twenty-first floor of Grenfell and had been amongst the last people to leave the building. On their way down they had to step over dying bodies. They were obviously still deeply shocked and upset by what they had endured. And her...

Name: Diane Abbott
Message: Retro-fitting sprinklers saves lives, saves homes and saves money - Diane Abbott MP writes for PoliticsHome : One thing the Government should immediately do in the wake of the Grenfell tragedy is the compulsory retro-fitting of sprinklers in all tower blocks, major residential buildings, and student accommodation. Earlier this week, the Communities Secretary Sajid Javid MP, told the House of Commons that the recommendations of the Coroner‚Äôs report into the fire at Lakanal House had been implemented ‚Äòfully‚Äô. But many people who live in blocks will know that this is simply not true, as even during refurbishments in recent years their buildings have not been retrofitted with sprinklers. After the Grenfell Tower fire residents in tower block and others across the country will be concerned that they could be at risk. They need reassurance ‚Äì and installing sprinklers would do just that. When challenged on this Tory Ministers want to hide behind the fact that there is an official Inquiry....

Name: Diane Abbott
Message: Hit SHARE now if you agree with Diane Abbott MP - cuts to our fire and rescue service need to end ‚Üì ARTICLE: Tories decimate fire services Figures obtained by the Fire Brigades Union (FBU) last month show that under Tory austerity almost one in fivefront-line firefighter posts ‚Äî some 11,000 jobs ‚Äî have been lost since 2010, making it a post war record. Firefighter jobs have been cut across Britain for seven years now and in total, these cuts mean that 19 per cent of the entire firefighting workforce has been slashed. Almost 8,000 of the total jobs lost since 2010 are to full-time firefighter posts and additionally nearly 3,000 ‚Äúretained‚Äù (on-call) jobs have gone. Over 1,000 firefighter jobs have been lost in Scotland, 300 in Wales and around 100 in Northern Ireland. Such cuts have consequences, whatever the Tories may claim, and are putting the public at risk. As Matt Wrack, general secretary of the FBU, said: ‚ÄúAfter a tragedy like Grenfell Tower, the public need to feel safe. It...

Name: Diane Abbott
Message: From Jeremy Corbyn: I would like to wish Muslims in Britain and across the world Eid Mubarak. During Hajj, the Muslim pilgrimage, Muslims from all over the world to come together to pray for humanity, to reflect on themselves and to commemorate the Prophet Ibrahim. Today, Muslims remember this story by carrying its message with them. A message of compassion for those less fortunate and of sharing what we have with others. These values are more relevant today than ever. We must come together in our communities and as a society to draw strength from our shared humanity. This year, I have travelled across the country and visited many mosques. I have seen the work Muslims are doing in their communities; volunteering in foodbanks and community centers, and supporting the families of Grenfell Tower. That is the true spirit of Eid. From myself, and on behalf of the Labour Party, I wish you Eid Mubarak.

Name: Diane Abbott
Message: Important from Chris Williamson MP : "Grenfell should be recognised as a chapter in Britain‚Äôs failed experiment with the free market. Other symptoms of this dogma include in-work poverty, crippling student debt, financial instability, homelessness - the list goes on. Over three decades of neoliberalism has created a wide-spread appetite for change to a degree that didn‚Äôt exist in the same way in the early 1980s. Unlike many of his peers, Corbyn was lucky enough to have never swallowed the pill of neoliberalism, while many of today‚Äôs younger generation, and those left behind by globalisation, have never seen the appeal. The zeitgeist has now shifted and with instances like Grenfell, people increasingly feel it in their bones that system change is desperately needed; these are the foundations for a Corbyn-led Labour government."

Name: Diane Abbott
Message: It‚Äôs time to end the chaos at the Home Office and restore a sense of order and trust, writes Diane Abbott MP for PoliticsHome: Leaked documents, misconceived policies, suppressed reports, judicial condemnations, false statistics and ‚Äòaccidental‚Äô deportations ‚Äì the summer recess was hardly a period of calm for the Home Office. Grenfell survivors are still living with the threat of deportation, deaths in police custody continue, police stations are being closed and the fire service continues to be run down. The Home Office is the government department primarily responsible for the safety and security of our citizens. Yet under the Tory government, the failure to exercise this duty is exposed across all fronts. Each of these failings must be addressed thoroughly and urgently. But they also appear to be symptomatic of a deeper malaise, which must be rooted out to prevent a recurrence of this chaos. Departments have their priorities set by the government of the day. It has been the...

Name: Diane Abbott
Message: Important recent piece from Diane Abbott MP - The government is risking another Grenfell disaster. Fire statistics released yesterday make for alarming reading: incidents have increased by 9 per cent compared to the previous year. The statistics include the catastrophic Grenfell Tower fire, which cost the lives of 71 people. The Fire Brigades Union describes it as the UK‚Äôs worst fire in terms of deaths within living memory. However, the government‚Äôs response is lacking on many fronts. As of last month, 299 of 312 high rise buildings with Grenfell-style cladding have failed safety tests, and only three of these buildings have completed cladding replacement. There are thousands of towers in social housing schemes, student accommodation and privately-owned blocks across the country in which residents will be sleeping uneasy for fear of a repeat of the Grenfell Tower disaster. Confidence in the government‚Äôs fire safety testing also took another blow last week when the safety report for...

Name: Diane Abbott
Message: "This is what the Tory housing crisis looks like: deposits from ¬£210 in the 1960s to tens of thousands of pounds now, ‚Äúmy rent is nearly as much as I earn‚Äù, knocking down housing estates, agent fees, Christmas spent in wholly unsuitable emergency accommodation missing basic facilities, slum landlords raking in housing benefit. Name: Diane Abbott
Message: "Theresa May has finally agreed to appoint a panel of experts to the Grenfell inquiry. This decision took a petition initiated by the survivors and bereaved families, thousands of signatures and an unrelenting campaign. This was a stress that the survivors and bereaved should not have had to face, and could have been spared if she had respected their wishes from the outset. It is right to welcome the appointment of two members on the panel for phase two of the inquiry looking at the circumstances surrounding the fire as a step in the right direction ‚Äì but it does not go far enough." - Diane Abbott MP

Name: Dr Phillip Lee
Message: MEETING OUR CHIEF FIRE OFFICER On Friday 6th October I met Royal Berkshire Fire and Rescue Service‚Äôs new Chief Fire Officer and Chief Executive, Trevor Ferguson at my Bracknell office. Trevor took up the role in April having previously been Deputy Chief Fire Officer and, before that, served for over 26 years with the Northern Ireland Fire and Rescue Service. He explained the challenges being faced in Berkshire as a result of the significant growth in high-rise residential development, the conversion of office blocks into living accommodation and the need for the Service to balance safety with supporting economic growth. When tragedies such as Grenfell Tower occur, it is very easy to forget that domestic fire incidents and deaths have declined steadily and significantly over the last decade. That is a tremendous testament to the work done by the Fire Services in their often overlooked but equally important role of fire prevention. It is quite clear from our meeting that Trevor has...

Name: Dr Rosena Allin
Message: My very first week as a doctor was the week of the 7/7 bombings. I know from day one what terror attacks do to the emergency services. An incredible amount of work goes into preparing for multiple casualties. And the emergency services themselves can be very nervous. It‚Äôs a very daunting time. But without fail, our emergency services step up. It was no different during the London Bridge attack. The police officers who answered - within minutes - the first call had no idea what they were going into. It is times like that we really do see the best of our services. We must never take for granted the sacrifices they make. Each time there is a terror attack or a tragedy like Grenfell, we see our emergency services doing us proud. We see off-duty medics, police, firefighters coming in to help their teams. And that‚Äôs to save as many lives as possible. I worked with Dr Martin Griffiths when I was at the Royal London and he‚Äôs a great example of this. Martin was off duty when the London...

Name: Gill Furnissgh
Message: My reaction to the Queens Speech: ------------------------------------------------------------------ Lacking authority and vision, the Tories lacklustre proposals in the Queen‚Äôs Speech provide little hope for the British people. Despite continued tax cuts for the richest in our society, the speech offered no increase in desperately needed public spending for the NHS, school and policing. Theresa May has totally failed to listen to voters up and down the country who plainly rejected continued austerity by not giving her the majority she sought. This is a humiliating Queens Speech from a weakened Prime Minister. Theresa May personally campaigned to bring back grammar schools, scrapping free school meals, ending the triple-lock and bringing back fox hunting ‚Äì none of which eventually made it in the Queens Speech. In contrast, The Labour Manifesto captured the heart of the nation ‚Äì offering hope, prosperity and opportunity for all. Almost 2 weeks since the election in which Theresa May...

Name: Gill Furnissgh
Message: I've just spoken in the debate on Product Safety and Fire risk in residential homes. In Sheffield, faulty white goods caused 103 fires in residential homes between April 2014- march 2017 according to the South Yorkshire Fire and Rescue Department. This year the country was shocked by the tragedy at Grenfell Tower thoughts to have started because of a faulty fridge freezer. There is a near consensus from consumer bodies that the current product safety regime is not fit-for-purpose. Government have been slow to act but I will continue to push the Government on this issue.

Name: Gordon Marsden
Message: Busy time this week after returning from Westminster on Wednesday evening, with local events in Blackpool South for The Great Get Together, which marks a year since the sad and senseless death of Jo Cox MP. Very sombre day with both remembrance of Jo and the awful scenes from Grenfell Tower, but buoyed by positive response at Abbeyfield House in South Shore and Highfield Leadership Academy, both of whom hosted events to raise funds for the Jo Cox Foundation. This week I also saw the progress being made at the Enterprise Zone, as well as monitoring the situation with the fire on Lytham Rd. Happy to see no casualties. If you'd like to learn more about the work the Jo Cox Foundation does our donate, you can do so here: https://www.jocoxfoundation.org

Name: Gordon Marsden
Message: It was a privilege to be at St Anne's Synagogue today with the Mayor of Blackpool and many others for Holocaust Memorial Day. It was a very moving service with a powerful address on the "Power of Words" theme by Milena Grenfell-Barnes - a holocaust survivor brought to England. There were also powerful presentations on the theme by Blackpool and Fylde schools at the service. A special thanks to Stephen Conway from St Mary's Catholic College for coordinating the students so well. Yesterday I also signed Holocaust Memorial Day Book of Commitment in Westminster along with my fellow Parliamentarians.

Name: Grant Shapps
Message: They say a week's a long time in politics, so a year must seem like an eternity. Who could have foreseen a year ago that unexpected General Election, those shocking terrorist attacks on London & Manchester and the sheer human suffering of Grenfell Tower? As ever, it's been a year of contrasts. Locally, we have seen some good outcomes, like the re-opening of the Post Office in Welwyn Garden City and continued record falls in unemployment; meaning more people have jobs than ever before in our area. And, as we look to 2018, there's much more to be done here in Welwyn Hatfield. So I'll be launching the 'Make Healthcare Local' campaign, to try and convince health bosses that, with a growing population, we need more health services in our community; rather than miles away. And I'll be campaigning for the widening of the A1M Motorway, with 'Smart running' to reduce the queues at rush hour. But, of course, some of the most significant events of 2018 will also be the hardest to predict. So...

Name: Helen Hayes
Message: The Grenfell Tower fire is an appalling tragedy which has shocked us all. There must be a public inquiry to uncover the detail of the decision making which led to fire safety being compromised with such devastating consequences, but it is already clear that the fire should never have happened. I have written to the Prime Minister to call for immediate action to protect residents of tower blocks, on the basis of advice the government has already received. We must ensure that such an appalling tragedy can never happen again.

Name: Helen Hayes
Message: Today I asked the Minister about the Government‚Äôs shocking admission that councils will be expected to ‚Äòreprioritise‚Äô from within already stretched budgets to pay for essential fire safety works post-Grenfell. This will mean that the long term consequence of the Grenfell Tower fire across the country is a deepening of the housing crisis, as Councils are forced to spend funding allocated for urgently needed new homes, or much needed refurbishment works on sprinkler systems and other essential fire safety measures. This is simply not good enough. The Grenfell Tower fire was a national disaster and the government owes it to the survivors and victims of Grenfell to do better than this. I am calling on the Government to provide grant funding to all councils that require it.

Name: Helen Whately
Message: This New Year I want to say a big thank you to our incredible emergency services and first responders. Most of us look forward to a few days off at Christmas, but for people who work in A&Es, ambulance services, the police, NHS 111, mental health crisis teams and volunteers with charities like Age UK and the Samaritans, the work continues. With Grenfell Tower, the Manchester bombing, disgraceful attacks on Westminster and London Bridge - Britain has suffered too many terrible tragedies this year. But we have come through. That we are still standing firm and looking forward to a better future is only possible thanks to the incredible bravery and hard work of the emergency and security services. Not only have they responded to terrible attacks, they have also prevented them. I pay particular tribute to the police and others who kept me, my colleagues and staff safe during the Westminster attack, even as they were grieving for the loss of one of their own: PC Keith Palmer. I hope that...

Name: Ian Austin
Message: Lots of residents have been in touch about the catastrophic fire in Grenfell Tower block. My thoughts are with those who are affected by this tragedy and I‚Äôm in awe at the incredible response of our emergency services and the local community who have come together to support those affected. I‚Äôve written to the Prime Minister asking her to update fire safety regulations and improve safety for residents in the future. I will be following this very closely and will push to ensure that the inquiry covers all relevant areas, including building and fire regulations. I've also met with Dudley Council to discuss the safety of high-rise blocks of flats in the borough.

Name: Ian Blackford
Message: This morning the Prime Minister brought an emergency statement to the House on the Grenfell Tower disaster. It is of great concern to many people living in high rise accommodation not only in London, but across the country. It is very important that lessons learned from this tragedy are made publicly available and acted upon to calm fears, identify necessary upgrades and make real changes to fire safety regulations to protect these people.

Name: James Brokenshire
Message: Had a useful catch-up meeting with Councillor Teresa O'Neill, the Leader of Bexley Council and David Evennett MP at the Civic Offices in Bexleyheath earlier to discuss a number of local issues. Included a discussion about the horrific fire at Grenfell Tower. Cllr O'Neill said that the Council had taken steps to confirm with the Borough's housing associations that all the appropriate risk assessments and fire safety checks were in place. Also heard how London Borough of Bexley staff had been providing help and support to Kensington & Chelsea as they dealt with the significant consequences of this terrible incident.

Name: James Cleverly
Message: Grenfell Tower fire Like many people I have been shocked and saddened beyond measure by the terrible fire in Grenfell Tower. The loss of so many lives in such a horrific way is numbing. I have paused before commenting because of there has been a huge amount of speculation on social media and in the mainstream media, I didn't want to add to that. The Prime Minister was right to call for an enquiry to run in parallel with the fire service investigation. Clearly something (or things) went very badly wrong and we need to find out promptly what happened in case emergency remedial action needs to be taken in other similar high rise buildings. As you can see from the Prime Minister's letter to MPs the government has put in place an action plan to help those affected by the fire and also ensure we are able to protect other residents of tall buildings.

Name: James Cleverly
Message: Voting against the "Homes fit for Human Habitation Bill because I am a Landlord" - Nice meme, but it isn't true. In response the the terrible fire and loss of life at Grenfell Tower a number of people have criticised me for voting against Labour's "Homes Fit For Human Habitation Bill". They highlight my parliamentary declaration of interests showing that I was a private landlord and imply (or state) that I did so out of financial self interest. Almost every element of those accusations is untrue. I don't usually respond to baseless accusations but this one is particularly pernicious and is being linked to the tragedy at Grenfell Tower. So in this instance I think it deserves a response. The bill that I am accused of voting down was in fact a Labour amendment to the government's Housing and Planning Bill. The amendment tried to bring in some clauses from a private member's bill that failed to make progress, as is the case with the vast majority of private member's bills. I voted...

Name: Jeremy Corbyn
Message: I was devastated this morning to see reports of the fire that took place at Grenfell Tower overnight. My thoughts are with the victims, their loved ones and all those affected. Thank you to our brave firefighters and emergency services who put themselves at risk to save lives today, and every day. I would also like to praise the community for coming together to help the hundreds of people who have been made homeless. This kindness and solidarity towards those in need shows Britain at its best. You can donate food, clothes, toys and bedding to the following drop off points: RUGBY PORTBELLO TRUST 221 Walmer Road, W11 4EY ST CLEMENT'S CHURCH 95 Sirdar Road, W11 4EQ TABERNACLE CHRISTIAN CENTRE Jubilee House, 210 Latimer Road, W10 6QY

Name: Jeremy Corbyn
Message: I have written to the Prime Minister asking for the terms of the Grenfell fire inquiry to be broadened and for residents to be heard throughout the process. It is clear to me from talking to Grenfell residents that their concerns and questions stretch beyond the current narrow terms of the inquiry. I have suggested a two part inquiry, with the first part looking at the specific issues around Grenfell and reporting back quickly and the second part looking at the national issues. I have also urged for an interim report as ongoing uncertainty and long delays would add to the trauma Grenfell residents and victims‚Äô families have already experienced. The Prime Minister must commit to taking action now on areas not related to the outcome of the inquiry, including identifying all those missing or dead, amnesty for victims concerned at immigration status, providing permanent in-borough accommodation to all residents, committing up-front funding for councils, and overhauling building...

Name: Jeremy Corbyn
Message: I have written to Theresa May with Labour's recommendations on the Terms of Reference of the Inquiry into Grenfell Tower. We are recommending a two-part inquiry into Grenfell. The first, to get answers to urgent questions about what happened at Grenfell. The second, a more wide-ranging inquiry into the underlying causes of the fire and its national implications. We have also urged broader, diverse membership of the Grenfell Tower Inquiry team, ensuring residents are represented and feel confident in the process.

Name: Jeremy Corbyn
Message: This weekend over a million people will attend Notting Hill Carnival, one of Britain's most iconic events. Carnival emerged as a response to bigotry and hatred faced by black communities. It united people through art, music and dance in celebration of Caribbean culture, black history and our diverse and multicultural society. This year's Carnival comes as we mourn the tragedy of the Grenfell Tower fire. This important event aims to help the local community to heal, as the very first Carnival did in the 1960s. Carnival-goers will not only celebrate Carnival, but also reflect on inequality and injustice in our society and resolve to work together to overcome them. The Carnival is beautifully captured in Benjamin Zephaniah's poem, Carnival Days: On days like these we dance to us, With the drum beat of liberation Under the close cover of European skies, We dance like true survivors We dance to the sounds of our dreams. ... On dis rocking British cultural crown, When Rio‚Äôs eyes upon us...
