Name: Jeremy Corbyn
Message: I would like to wish Muslims in Britain and across the world Eid Mubarak. During Hajj, the Muslim pilgrimage, Muslims from all over the world to come together to pray for humanity, to reflect on themselves and to commemorate the Prophet Ibrahim. Today, Muslims remember this story by carrying its message with them. A message of compassion for those less fortunate and of sharing what we have with others. These values are more relevant today than ever. We must come together in our communities and as a society to draw strength from our shared humanity. This year, I have travelled across the country and visited many mosques. I have seen the work Muslims are doing in their communities; volunteering in foodbanks and community centers, and supporting the families of Grenfell Tower. That is the true spirit of Eid. From myself, and on behalf of the Labour Party, I wish you Eid Mubarak.

Name: Jeremy Corbyn
Message: Tonight, I was honoured to present Stormzy with the British GQ Solo Artist Of The Year award. This last year we have seen dramatic political events across the world. And against that backdrop we have seen the emergence of incredible, powerful artists. None more so than Stormzy who ‚Äì instead of signing to a major record label ‚Äì has used his own label to top the charts and change the face of music in this country. He is one of London‚Äôs most inspiring young men, encouraging his listeners to vote, pray and speak openly about mental health. Whether speaking out against racism or supporting the victims of Grenfell, he‚Äôs remained true to his roots and committed to his values throughout.

Name: Jo Churchill
Message: These past two weeks have marked a busy return to Parliament; with urgent issues to discuss from the tragedy at Grenfell Tower to the future of our services. In debate on the Queen‚Äôs Speech I contributed to the discussion, outlining the economic progress achieved in the past seven years and how this has served my Bury St Edmunds constituency, as well as by making a positive case for what we should be looking towards to ensure success. With a thriving small business sector across my constituency, I highlighted how important it is to support our businesses to create jobs and generate taxes; we must deliver on both. It is evident that fiscal responsibility and support for businesses has nurtured growth in areas like Suffolk but, as I stated, it is right we look to make future investments particularly in infrastructure for our future generations. This I believe will be a crucial debate going forward and I was pleased to have been able to speak up, at this stage, and make the case for...

Name: Joan Ryan
Message: READ & SHARE: I have been contacted by several concerned constituents, following the tragedy at the Grenfell Tower in Kensington. I have sought reassurances from the Chief Executive of Enfield Council regarding the safety of residential blocks in Enfield. I am grateful for the prompt response from Ian Davis and for his statement on the issue which I provide below: ‚ÄúA letter is being prepared which will go out to all residents in tower blocks this week. However we can assure you that all 52 tower blocks in the borough received a full fire risk assessment in 16/17 and will do so again this year. Caretakers inspect the blocks daily, checking fire doors and any other risk issues, and liaise regularly with neighbourhood staff. An additional round of inspections specifically focusing on fire risk will take place on Thursday [15th June] and Friday [16th June]. We believe our blocks are safe, but we are not complacent and will ensure that we learn from the dreadful experiences in west...

Name: John McDonnell
Message: I've called on the government to immediately let councils have the resources to make our tower blocks safe. The tragic fire that occurred on Grenfell Tower must never be allowed to happen again. The lessons of Camberwell, Shepherds Bush and Southampton have not been learned, and it is the responsibility of government to provide solutions. The Government must now as a matter of urgency lift the housing revenue account borrowing cap to free councils to undertake the urgent retrofitting work required on all existing housing stock found not to meet required safety standards. Councils must also be given the power to borrow to invest in council housing on the scale necessary to allow all those living in homes deemed to be unsafe to be properly rehoused.

Name: John McDonnell
Message: The public have lost trust in Theresa May and the Conservatives. People are fed up with a pay freeze, poverty wages, an NHS in crisis, being shackled with lifelong debt and no secure home. The Tories had their chance and they've failed. It's up to everyone of us to make sure they step aside so we can have a Government that cares for the many, not the few. Join me on the People's Assembly demonstration this Saturday.

Name: John McNally
Message: My thoughts in the Falkirk Herald... THIS election night was very different from the last. My wife and I walked into the polling station accompanied by armed police - a visible sign of country‚Äôs mood following the appalling terrorist attacks in Manchester and London. It was also markedly quieter than 2015, with staff and candidates outnumbering members of the public. There was little flag waving. When the results were read out, I was, and remain, honoured to have been chosen by the people of Falkirk to be their MP. My majority was cut but I have been voted back to continue building on the work for the community I‚Äôve achieved over the past two years. I could not have done it without those who generously gave up their time and put so much work into our deeply positive Falkirk campaign. I am proud to have been part of it. The campaign trail was a pleasure to experience. We met many people with lots to say. On election day, a beautiful bride turned out to meet us, resplendent in her...

Name: Jon Cruddas
Message: Following the tragedy at Grenfell Tower earlier this week my sincerest thoughts are with the people that lost their lives, those that are still unaccounted for, and their families and friends. This incident raises serious questions of accountability and I agree with many of my parliamentary colleges that a full inquiry is the way forward. This tragedy has also increased the concerns of residents closer to home. Today I will be contacting the Chief Executives of Barking and Dagenham and Havering strongly urging both councils to carry out full safety audits as a matter of urgency for all the tower blocks, and low rise flats within my constituency. If anyone has any concerns please do not hesitate in contacting me at cruddasj@parliament.uk or my office on 020 8984 7854

Name: Jon Trickett
Message: Following the tragic fire at Grenfell Tower in London, there is an understandable level of anxiety and concern surrounding the safety of multi-storey tower blocks. Today I received a letter from Kevin Dodd, the Chief Executive of Wakefield and District Housing (WDH) assuring the safety of residents in WDH multi-storey blocks. Mr Dodd firstly reassured me that WDH use a completely different kind of cladding from the type used at Grenfell Tower in London. The cladding used by WDH has a fully compliant fire retardant rating from the manufacturer. He also gave assurances that all WDH flats comply with all fire safety requirements, and are inspected every three months by West Yorkshire Fire and Rescue Service. I have been told that there is a rigorous inspection regime currently in place to make sure all the accesses are clear at all times and each flat has a hard wired smoke and heat detector. All the lifts meet the requirements to ensure firefighters are able to use them in case of...

Name: Jon Trickett
Message: Excited to announce that @emmadentcoad has been appointed as my PPS; one of our greatest campaigners who won the prize seat of Kensington in June & now fighting for justice for Grenfell

Name: Jonathan Reynolds
Message: In the aftermath of the appalling tradegedy at Grenfall Tower, I am in regular contact with local housing associations, fire services and the council regarding fire safety in our local tower blocks. I will be pushing the government not just for a full review of fire regulations but for an examination into the resource levels of our uniformed services. New Charter manages three blocks which might be described as ‚Äòtowers‚Äôin my constituency: Chartist, John Grundy & Thompson Court. There are no longer any "tower" style blocks in Hattersley. This is the lateset update I received from them: "We have current Fire Risk Assessments for all the properties and we had already identified the need for further assessments to quantify what further work might be needed particularly around ensuring the right degree of compartmentalisation was present. In order to ensure the right levels of compliance we had already engaged independent expert advisors to ensure nothing was missed. I have also now...

Name: Jonathan Reynolds
Message: An afternoon of two halves. Firstly, the exhilaration of having our Parliamentary Labour Party "class photo". It's inspiring to see so many Labour colleagues returned and so many new ones elected -this, after an election the right wing press nastily predicted would be "blue murder". We are the most diverse PLP ever in terms of gender, ethnicity and disability- a proud moment. Secondly, however, our amendment to stop cuts and caps to the pay of police, firefighters and nurses was narrowly lost, by 14 votes (10 of them bought from the DUP). It is the height of hypocrisy that the Tories have repeatedly praised our emergency services and NHS through weeks of terrible terror attacks and the tragedy at Grenfell, but in the very first vote of this Parliament, moved to continue freezing their pay. The difference a Labour Government would make has never been starker.

Name: Jonathan Reynolds
Message: I've been at MediaCity this afternoon filming the North West part of this weekend's Sunday Politics. Tune in on Sunday to see us cover the Conservatives' deal with the DUP and whether it means the North West will miss out, the announcement that charges will finally be brought over Hillsborough and the response from the Govt and the Opposition to the Grenfell Tower disaster.

Name: Julian Smith
Message: I am deeply shocked and saddened by the fire at Grenfell Tower. My thoughts are with those affected and their friends and family. The Government is committed to a full public inquiry into this terrible incident and the Government will make a statement shortly.

Name: Julian Smith
Message: I am deeply shocked and saddened by the fire at Grenfell Tower. My thoughts are with those affected and their friends and family.

Name: Julian Sturdy
Message: Throughout the day I have been shocked by the horrific images on the television of the Grenfell Tower in North Kensington. Sadly, we know that at least six people have lost their lives in this shocking incident and many more are being treated in hospitals across the capital. My thoughts and prayers are with all of the people caught up in this dreadful event Once again, our emergency services have exhibited their professionalism and bravery in the most testing of circumstances. I believe I speak on behalf of all residents of York Outer when I say that we are truly grateful for all they do to keep us safe.

Name: Julie Cooper
Message: Like most people I have found the news from Grenfell following the fire really distressing. All thoughts and prayers are with the victims and their families. Calico, our leading provider of social housing in Burnley and Padiham continually review the safety of their properties in conjunction with fire safety officers. I was reassured to hear that they do not use the same materials for cladding as were used in Grenfell.

Name: Julie Elliott
Message: This week I wrote to the Government's housing minister about proposals to convert Angel House, in Borough Road, from a commercial office block to a residential tower block. I am really concerned that, due to changes made by the Coalition Government between 2010 and 2015, this conversion could go ahead without a full planning application and robust public scrutiny. It‚Äôs not right that developers are able to convert non-residential buildings into residential tower blocks through the process that is normally used for small home improvements. I find this very worrying, especially in light of the Grenfell Tower atrocity. This loophole could potentially put my constituents at risk. Read the Echo story on it here:

Name: Julie Elliott
Message: I have urged the Government to ensure councils and housing associations have the funds to make properties safe in the wake of the Grenfell tragedy. Cladding which failed fire safety tests was removed from five Sunderland tower blocks in June. That work was done quickly and the buildings are safe, but obviously more work was then needed to put them into a good state. I have asked the Secretary of State to assure me that funding will be made available not just to local authorities, but also to the smaller housing associations with that responsibility. See more here: http://bit.ly/2v1rcWk:=:https://www.julie4sunderland.co.uk/funds_needed_to_make_buildings_safe

Name: Justin Tomlinson
Message: I joined the Fire Service and Clls last week to visit the high rise towers in Penhill to reassure residents that in the wake of the tragic fire at Grenfell Tower, their buildings are completely up to fire safety standards and there is no reason to worry. Residents have been assured that the high rise buildings in the area are completely brick cladded and lack any combustible cladding, such as composite aluminium cladding that was seen in the tragedy at Grenfell Tower. Both blocks I visited are also protected by regularly inspected fire alarm systems and fireproof doors.

Name: Kate Green
Message: Parliament isn't formally in session yet; MPs are still being sworn in (I was sworn in this morning), and the state opening of parliament by the queen is on 21 June. But an emergency meeting was arranged this afternoon so that MPs could question ministers about the tragic fire in Grenfell Tower in west London. This was an appalling event, and MPs are determined to get answers and to prevent such an awful event ever happening again. Ministers were asked about fire safety standards, about rehousing and support for those affected by the fire, about government funding to bring all buildings up to safe standards, about possible corporate manslaughter charges, and about the public inquiry announced by the prime minister. I was one of a number of MPs to demand clear advice be made available about what people should do in the event of a fire breaking out in their building, as a matter of urgency. I have also been in contact with the boss of Trafford Housing Trust, who own a number of tower...

Name: Kate Green
Message: Parliament isn't formally in session yet; MPs are still being sworn in (I was sworn in this morning), and the state opening of parliament by the Queen has been set for 21 June. But an emergency meeting was arranged this afternoon for MPs to question ministers about the appalling fire in Grenfell Tower in west London. Many questions were raised, about fire safety regulations, about rehousing and support for those affected, about government funding for all buildings to be brought up to safe standards, about possible corporate manslaughter charges, and about the public inquiry announced by the prime minister. I was one of a number of MPs to ask for clear advice that people should follow if a fire breaks out in their building, as a matter of urgency. I have also been in contact with the boss of Trafford Housing Trust, who own a number of tower blocks in Stretford and Urmston. THT have checked their buildings, and tell me they use a different, non flammable, cladding from that used on...

Name: Kate Green
Message: Since last week's appalling fire at Grenfell Tower last week, MPs have been keeping a careful watch on developments. I understand fire safety was discussed extensively at Trafford Housing Trust's board meeting this week. THT tell me costings are being obtained for new fire safety measures, and assessments being carried out on all tower blocks. I am assured the findings will be shared with residents. I also understand that new liaison arrangements with residents are being put in place. In the meantime, the advice to residents remains to stay put in your flat in the event of a fire, but that will be reviewed to see if any change to the advice is necessary. Fire safety was also discussed in parliament this morning, when the prime minister made a statement to MPs. You can read a transcript of proceedings in parliament at https://hansard.parliament.uk/commons/2017-06-22/debates/E4B84F46-4699-4725-BBE4-AA724C3A0191/GrenfellTower . The Prime Minister said that inspections have shown that...

Name: Kate Green
Message: Parliament received a further update on fire safety in tower blocks from the Secretary of State yesterday. You can read a trasncript of his statement and the questions asked by MPs (inlcuding me) at http://hansard.parliament.uk/commons/2017-07-03/debates/AC706A82-B504-4E3B-9797-85F6B2F20295/GrenfellTower. A number of residents in tower blocks in Stretford and Urmston have raised queries about fire safety with me. I am in contact withTrafford Housing Trust, Irwell Valley and Trafford Council for more information, and will continue to ask questions in parliament. Please don't hesitate to get in touch with me if you have any concerns or queries. Trafford Housing Trust tell me they have instituted 'walking watches' in their blocks to make staff available to residents.

Name: Kate Green
Message: I was glad to be able to contribute to today's debate in parliament on fire safety, following last month's appalling fire in Grenfell Tower in west London. You can read a transcript of the debate at http://hansard.parliament.uk/commons/2017-07-12/debates/2CAD3EEE-C6CD-4048-B6A8-13586A284727/GrenfellTowerFireInquiry I'm continuing to liaise with landlords in Trafford regarding safety in our tower blocks. Don't hesitate to get in touch with me if you have any concerns about this.

Name: Kate Green

Name: Kate Green
Message: We've just reached the end of this year's Labour party conference, and I'm setting off for home. It's been a packed out few days, with lots of exciting announcements of new policies that Labour will introduce in government. Promises to introduce a national education service and create new regional investment banks as the building blocks for a prosperous future. Promises of investment in our public services, and fair pay for public sector workers like police officers, firefighters and NHS staff. A commitment to decent housing for everyone - a particularly poignant promise as we remember the victims of the terrible fire in Grenfell Tower. Promises to end exploitative credit card interest costs, and to return essential services to public control. Jeremy Corbyn in his closing speech to conference also talked about our global commitments and responsibilities. I was very pleased to hear him call on Aung San Suu Kyi to end the terrible violence against the Rohingya Muslims in Burma. And...

Name: Kate Green
Message: Great to welcome the Fire Brigades Union to parliament this week. Firefighters in Greater Manchester have faced some demanding times recently, such as the Arena attack, and making safety checks on our tower blocks following the Grenfell Tower tragedy. It was really nice to be able to say thank you in person

Message: The Grenfell Tower fire was the end result of a disdainful housing policy | Pilgrim Tucker https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2017/jun/20/grenfell-fire-housing-policy-social-housing-tenants?CMP=share_btn_tw

Name: Kate Hollern
Message: This week, I‚Äôve seen Tory MPs cheer as they voted down a pay rise for public sector workers. These are firefighters and nurses, the everyday heroes who keep Britain running. Over the past few months, the tragedies that have taken place across Britain have moved the nation. From firefighters at Grenfell tower to police at London Bridge and first responders to Manchester & Finsbury Park. Labour put forward a reasonable and responsible amendment to the Queen‚Äôs Speech to end the public sector pay cap and end cuts to emergency services. Our Shadow Health Secretary, Jon Ashworth, spoke of nurses forced to use foodbanks as their pay had not kept pace with inflation. Unfortunately, the motion fell by 14 votes. When it is politically convenient, the Tories will praise public sector workers. When it is good for photo ops, they will stand alongside them. But when it comes to the day to day business of the House of Commons, they revert back to austerity for public services but a bonanza for...

Name: Kate Hollern
Message: The Grenfell tragedy highlighted the absolute necessity of making tower blocks safe for residents. The Chancellor must provide funds to offer some peace of mind to those living in tower blocks across the country. #MakeHomesSafe https://twitter.com/jeremycorbyn/status/928527574061510656

Name: Kate Hollern
Message: Kate Hollern MP backs Labour legislation to protect renters from homes unfit for human habitation Kate Hollern MP is backing a Bill being introduced by Labour MP Karen Buck this Friday 19 January which will give renters a new legal right to ensure their home is ‚Äòfit for human habitation‚Äô. The new legislation, long campaigned for by Labour, could help renters in 162,000 dangerously unfit properties in the North West. Nationally, there are over one million rented properties containing the most serious ‚Äòcategory 1‚Äô hazards, including homes that have unsafe electrics, vermin infestations, or aren‚Äôt fire safe. The Labour Bill will give tenants new legal powers to enforce their right to a decent home by taking their landlord to court if the property they live in is not fit. This is a particularly important for council tenants such as those who lived in Grenfell Tower, because it is councils who are notionally responsible for enforcing standards, but local authorities can‚Äôt enforce...

Name: Kelly Tolhurst
Message: The disaster at Grenfell Tower was deeply upsetting and will change social housing forever once we have the answers to many searching questions. No doubt, without the bravery and determination of our fire and rescue services we could have been facing many more deaths but it is clear that it should not come down to this in the first place. I have been in contact with local social landlord mhs homes to clarify the safety standards of our local high rises and I welcome the improvements that have been made over the past year and beyond and I am relieved that no cladding is used on any of their buildings. Nevertheless, while reviews are conducted up and down the country, I will continue to work with mhs homes and Medway Council to ensure safety standards remain at the high level.

Name: Kerry McCarthy
Message: As details of last night's events in West London continue to emerge, my thoughts are with the victims of this tragedy and the brave firefighters who are still responding to it. I understand that Bristol City Council will be looking to see if any lessons need to be learned for housing blocks in the city.

Name: Kerry McCarthy
Message: The UK has been shaken by another terrorist attack, targeting worshippers near the Finsbury Park Mosque in London during the holy month of Ramadan. Regardless of their creed, colour, or religion, terrorists seek to divide us through fear - not just of them, but of one another. They seek to break down our communities through violence, with this latest act of terror committed almost a year to the day since the murder of my colleague Jo Cox MP by another far-right extremist. But we are stronger than them, and must remain more united than they could ever understand.

Name: Kerry McCarthy
Message: Since the tragic fire at Grenfell Tower in London, and with dozens of people either dead or missing, many of you have been getting in touch, understandably concerned about fire regulations. This morning, I was with firefighters, councillors and Marvin Rees, Mayor of Bristol at Butler House ‚Äì one of the four high-rise blocks in Bristol East ‚Äì to reassure residents. All 59 council-owned blocks in the city will be visited over the next few weeks. I was told by the firefighters that each block has a fire safety inspection every year, and that although the service is under pressure because of government cuts, they have not cut back on this essential work. I was also told that the cladding system used in Grenfell Tower was not used in any of the Bristol blocks. Bristol City Council has been spending ¬£2million per year for the last five years on improving fire safety in high rise blocks of flats. It plans to spend at least ¬£1million per year for the next ten years, mainly around...

Name: Kerry McCarthy
Message: This morning, during her statement on the Grenfell Tower fire, I asked Theresa May whether the Government will fund any fire safety works which Bristol City Council deem essential and, if they will, when they will pay for it. All she would say was that local authorities can discuss it with the Government. Unfortunately, Thangam Debbonaire MP for Bristol West couldn't get a better answer from her either, when she asked the Government to retrofit all flats with sprinklers, and fund this. Our fire service has seen cuts of ¬£5 million and lost 150 firefighter jobs since 2010. Bristol council has been hit hard by hundreds of millions of pounds of Government cuts, and mismanagement by the former Mayor. Their budgets are already stretched. They should not have to go cap in hand to Theresa May. She must commit now to the Government funding every penny of essential works to make our tower blocks safe.

Name: Kerry McCarthy
Message: Last week, I raised with the Minister for Policing, Fire, and Criminal Justice the huge cuts to Avon Fire & Rescue Service ‚Äì resulting in the loss of a quarter of its force ‚Äì and asked if it would take a disaster like Grenfell Tower or a terrorist attack to make the government realise how stretched services are. The Minister responded that the fire service‚Äôs success with fire prevention has meant resources can be cut because the risk is now lower. So it seems by their frightening logic we will have to wait until a disaster that our stretched services can‚Äôt respond to fast enough, before they are properly resourced.

Name: Kerry McCarthy
Message: I will be in Parliament this Friday to support Karen Buck‚Äôs Private Members‚Äô Bill, to strengthen tenants rights and put a duty on landlords to ensure the homes they rent out are fit for people to live in. When Karen first put her Homes (Fitness for Human Habitation) Bill to Parliament in 2015 it was blocked by the Tories, as was a Labour amendment to the Housing Bill. It‚Äôs good news that, post-Grenfell, the Housing, Communities and Local Government Secretary has now indicated his support for the Bill, although shocking that in this day and age there should be any doubt about it. We now need to make sure there is proper help and advice for tenants who need to enforce their rights, and tough action against revenge evictions by landlords.

Name: Kevin Foster
Message: An update from Kevin, after another busy week. Local MP Kevin Foster was promoted to become a Parliamentary Private Secretary at the Department of Communities and Local Government following the recent General Election. A vast amount of Kevin‚Äôs Westminster time since then has been taken up with helping to co-ordinate the Government‚Äôs response to the terrible tragedy at Grenfell Tower in West London. In addition to this Kevin has been contacted by over 100 of his constituents in Torbay who, understandably, have local fire safety concerns. Kevin attended a meeting at Torquay Fire Station recently as well as speaking with senior council officials to seek the fire safety reassurance that his constituents rightly require. Parliament breaks up for the summer recess on Thursday 20th July, and Kevin has another week of DCLG and Grenfell - fire related meetings coming up. Since first being elected in May 2015, Kevin's philosophy has been "A local MP all year round, and not just at election...

You are good people - and London MPs are telling me how incredibly moved and grateful Londoners are for Birmingham's help. Thank you.

Name: Liam Byrne
Message: For me, one of the most important passages in the Bible is Luke 10:29, where Jesus is challenged with a question: 'The man wanted to justify his actions, so he asked Jesus, "And who is my neighbour?" Jesus answered with the parable of the Good Samaritan. The summary? Our neighbour is anyone in need. In the year we've had since Jo Cox was murdered, we've had a divisive Brexit debate and a divisive American election, the London Bridge and Borough market attack, the outrage at Manchester Arena, the Westminster Bridge attack and murder of PC Keith Palmer, and now the Grenfell Tower tragedy. Those who know this truth, that our neighbours are anyone in need, have been what has kept our country strong. And I think the Queen put that brilliantly today.

Name: Lucy Powell
Message: For the many residents living in former council tower blocks, particularly in Hulme, Ancoats, Miles Platting and Newton Heath, I have contacted both the Council and local housing associations to ask for full fire assessments and for urgent communication with residents. The Chief Executive and Deputy Leader (responsible for housing) are taking this matter extremely seriously and will update me and residents as their investigations continue. I have also asked for robust discussions with developers, managing agents and free-holders of the many privately-owned towers blocks in city centre, Ancoats and elsewhere, to ensure these blocks meet the highest possible fire standards. Again, I will update residents as I get more news. Undoubtedly there will be many lessons to be learned from the Grenfell Tower disaster. I have long argued for tighter regulation and oversight in this area, particularly, in Manchester, for privately-owned blocks which continue to be built at a fast rate in our city.

Name: Lucy Powell
Message: I have received a reply from One Manchester who have given assurances that their 17 tower blocks were not redeveloped with the same product for cladding as the Grenfell Tower. The Chief Executive of One Manchester has also confirmed that they will carry out full reviews of the tower blocks, cladding, fire and safety arrangements by July and will share a copy of that full report with me. A letter outlining all these measures and advice for residence is being sent to all residents today.

Name: Lucy Powell
Message: Following on from my conversations with One Manchester earlier this month, I've now been advised that samples from the cladding on a number of tower blocks in Hulme and Moss Side have failed safety tests. The following tower blocks are affected: Westcott Court, Lower Moss Lane, Manchester M15 4HS Platt Court, Wilmslow Road, Manchester M14 5LT Fulton Court, Boundary Lane, Manchester M15 6NW Worsley Court, Wilmslow Road, Manchester M14 5LU Duffield Court, Brennan Close, Manchester M15 6NS I understand that a contractor has been appointed to remove the cladding as soon as possible and 24 hour security is currently on site at all the blocks, as part of additional safety measures implemented following the Grenfell tragedy earlier this month. I know this will be concerning for those of you living in these blocks and would like to reassure you that I'm following this closely and remain in close contact with One Manchester, the Council and Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Services. If...

During the Grenfell inquiry debate today, I asked the government to ensure private blocks were also covered.

Name: Lucy Powell
Message: Thanks to everyone who came to my meeting for residents of City Centre apartment blocks last night. Since the Grenfell tragedy, I've received a large number of emails from constituents concerned about the cladding and fire safety in their own blocks, and a number of residents raised some serious issues at the meeting last night. I'm keen to put forward representations on behalf of both social and private tenants to the local and national inquiries and it was helpful to hear the views of City Centre residents last night. I'm especially grateful to Bob Birtles from Greater Manchester Fire & Rescue Service, and Councillor Pat Karney who spoke about the new taskforce being set up to ensure private landlords are also carrying out all necessary checks.

Name: Lucy Powell
Message: Today in Parliament Maria Miller MP introduced a Fire Safety Information Bill which I am proud to co-sponsor. The Bill will improve the requirements for fire safety information for occupants of certain buildings, including high-rise residential buildings. I know from my inbox that many residents feel that they do not have enough information about the safety of their block and that building owners are not always transparent. This Bill will require a nominated ‚ÄúResponsible Person‚Äù to hold an annual meeting with residents of a high-rise building, to make available the fire risk assessment for the building and to address any fire safety concerns. You can read more about the Bill in the story below, with many of the concerns raised by residents in Basingstoke, mirrored in Manchester and elsewhere across the country. http://www.basingstokegazette.co.uk/news/16098766.MP_to_introduce_fire_safety_Bill_in_wake_of_Grenfell_Tower_tragedy/

Name: Maria Eagle
Message: I was deeply saddened and shocked to hear of the tragic loss of life caused by the Grenfell Tower fire last week, one of the worst fires the UK has ever seen. I was also horrified to discover that the Tenant Management Organisation, tasked with maintaining the building, had covered the block with a combustible cladding that is thought to have been responsible for the fire being so deadly. The Prime minister has since confirmed that the same material has been used for cladding in other tower blocks elsewhere in the country. Yesterday, I pressed the Theresa May to commit to taking concrete steps to make sure that any discovery of combustible cladding on tower blocks, similar to the cladding that added to the tragic scale of the Grenfell Tower fire, around the county will be dealt with as a matter of extreme urgency. To read more click below ‚¨áÔ∏è‚¨áÔ∏è‚¨áÔ∏è http://www.mariaeagle.org.uk/grenfell_tower_block_fire

Name: Marie Rimmer
Message: It's vital that the Hillsborough Law is brought forward as soon as possible by the government, to make sure justice is done and the truth is always revealed for victims and their families in cases such as Hillsborough, and now Grenfell. I've joined with many colleagues in writing to Theresa May, urging her to expedite the Hillsborough Law to save more families from the pain of injustice. https://www.theguardian.com/law/2017/oct/31/labour-mps-call-for-theresa-may-to-back-hillsborough-law

Name: Marion Fellows
Message: My heartfelt sympathies go to those affected by the Grenfell Tower fire. It is appalling that so many people have been affected by this tragic event. It is unclear what has caused the Grenfell fire, but there will be a full investigation into what caused these avoidable deaths which have rocked the country. Any inquiry must be thorough and transparent to make sure those responsible are held to account. Lessons are learned so that this tragedy cannot be repeated. The council have issued advice which I encourage residents to read. They have also outlined the measures they have in place to ensure peoples‚Äô safety which should provide reassurances. However, I have written to council leader Jim Logue asking him to reveal if the cladding on the outside of all towers in the constituency are non-flammable to address peoples‚Äô concerns. A council spokesperson has thankfully confirmed that they are non-flammable.

Name: Mark Garnier
Message: Wyre Forest MP Mark Garnier has met with Hereford and Worcester Fire Authority safety commander Mark Preece in the wake of the Grenfell Tower tragedy. With four tower blocks in Kidderminster, and many public buildings, Mark has been keen to understand the provisions that the Fire Authority has in place to keep Wyre Forest residents safe. In an hour long meeting with Mark Preece, Mark learnt of many factors that are important to tower block residents and what provisions the authority is making, both in emergency action, but also in prevention measures. Matters discussed included details of intelligence about higher risk structures, strategy for fire prevention, routine checks and a host of other areas. These included: ‚Ä¢ All fire appliances are equipped with detailed information about every higher risk building, including floor plans, emergency strategies, alarms, sprinkers, fire strategies, escape routes, water sources and a host of other details vital to safe resolution of a fire...

Name: Mark Garnier
Message: View from Westminster 23rd June 2017 From time to time, when writing this column, there is far more to talk about than there is space to write. This is one of those weeks. On everyone‚Äôs mind is the utterly tragic fire at Grenfell Tower in London. I drove past it on my way out of London last week and to see the burnt out wreck of that building ‚Äì a building that was home to hundreds of families and households ‚Äì is to begin to understand the horror of that night when it burnt down. The news reports and images of that night, and the stories of the many personal tragedies that unfolded, are the stuff of nightmares. The stories of the actions of emergency services, the many, many individuals that acted as heroes helping their neighbours, and the rallying round by the wider community to help, are a tribute to the basic human nature that sees people behave in completely unselfish ways when called upon to help. It is inevitably the case that there will be enquiries into what happened, and a...

Name: Mark Garnier
Message: Since June 2017 following the tragic events at Grenfell Tower, Hereford and Worcester Fire and Rescue personnel have tried to make contact with residents in the High Rise premises in Wyre Forest. Hereford & Worcester Fire and Rescue Service have written to and knocked on all the homes within the High Rise Premises to offer safety checks which includes free advice and fitting of appropriate smoke detection. Unfortunately to date the uptake has been low at only 35%, Mark Garnier urges residents within these communities to accept this Free Home Fire Safety Check.

Name: Mark Harper
Message: Last night, a terrorist attack took place near the Finsbury Park mosque in London. My thoughts and prayers are with all those affected by this deplorable attack on innocent British Muslims, as they left their mosque having broken their fast and prayed together during the holy month of Ramadan. I would like to once again pay tribute to the swift response of our emergency services, and to the members of the public who put themselves in potential danger to keep people safe from this attack. The Prime Minister, Theresa May, said in Downing Street this morning: This morning, our country woke to news of another terrorist attack on the streets of our capital city: the second this month and every bit as sickening as those which have come before. It was an attack that once again targeted the ordinary and the innocent going about their daily lives ‚Äì this time British Muslims as they left a Mosque having broken their fast and prayed together at this sacred time of year. Today we come together...

Name: Mark Prisk
Message: Really pleased @theresa_may has widened #Grenfell panel for later phase of inquiry. @GrenfellUnited made fair and strong case.

Name: Mark Pritchard
Message: Just asked PQ on need for insurance companies to pay out quickly to Grenfell Tower victims

Name: Martin Docherty
Message: In the past week I have heard from a number of constituents who are understandably concerned about fire safety in high rise flats following the devastating fire at Grenfell Tower in London. Given the number of multi-storey buildings in West Dunbartonshire, I immediately contacted West Dunbartonshire Council to call for a review of its fire risk assessments and seek assurance that everything possible is being done to ensure these buildings meet the highest standards for fire safety. The council has now confirmed that it is commissioning Enhanced Fire Safety Risk Assessments for each of its multi-storey buildings in West Dunbartonshire. I also welcome the actions taken by the council in conjunction with the Scottish Fire & Rescue Service to issue fire safety guidance and provide reassurance to residents that these buildings are safe. Council officials assure me that every home in local multi-storey buildings has been issued with a letter and information on what to do in the event of...

Name: Martyn Day
Message: As more information emerges on the Grenfell Tower tragedy, it is important to keep pressure on the Government to ensure nothing like this terrible event is repeated. Since the very early days after the fire, There have been very disturbing news reports and statements from the Government on the extent of inadequacies in fire safety regulations. My SNP colleagues and I will work with all parties in the House of Commons to ensure that the families and friends of the victims of the fire at Grenfell, and the country more widely, get the answers that they need and deserve. Meanwhile positive work is continuing in Scotland where a Ministerial Working Group are reviewing fire safety measures to ensure housing in Scotland is as safe as it possibly can be.

Name: Mary Creagh
Message: Grenfell Tower is not an act of God, it's a man-made disaster. The firefighters and emergency services workers in London have done their job, now it's up to Ministers to do theirs.

Name: Matt Warman
Message: Following the Grenfell Tower tragedy in London a number of constituents have asked me for reassurance about the cladding on Boston's Pilgrim Hospital. I have been assured it is made of rockwool, and is therefore not a risk. I have provided private reassurance to people who have asked, and hope this public statement is helpful. I'd like to thank ULHT for proactively providing me with this information.

Name: Melanie Onn
Message: Following communication with Shoreline yesterday I will be meeting with them to ask about the fire safety of any cladding, discuss what other protections might be considered and the process for dealing with infirm or disabled residents in the event of an emergency situation such as the Grenfell Tower disaster in London this week. Ensuring emergency service access to all properties must also be considered. Shoreline fire safety advice: 'Important information for residents of Shoreline blocks and sheltered schemes Following the deeply upsetting fire at Grenfell Tower, London on 14 June 2017, we wanted to offer reassurance and guidance to our residents about the safety policies and procedures we have in place in our blocks of flats and sheltered schemes. Shoreline no longer has any occupied high-rise tower blocks but own and manage 195 low-rise blocks of flats and sheltered schemes across the borough. What we do to protect our tenants - All our blocks have up to date and effective...

Name: Melanie Onn
Message: I was so pleased that so many local people turned up for The Great Get Together last weekend. It‚Äôs a great demonstration of the strength of our community in Grimsby. People of all different ages and backgrounds came together to share a cup of tea, a piece of cake, and a friendly conversation with their neighbours. Everyone who attended wanted to see more gatherings like this, so I hope The Great Get Together will become an annual event. For so many people across the country to remember Jo Cox‚Äôs legacy in a positive way is exactly the right response to her murder. Thanks to the attendees for the generosity of their donations, raising ¬£200 for the victims of the Grenfell Tower disaster. Thanks also to the following businesses and charities that helped make the event a possible: Women's Aid Grimsby; GCW - Domestic & Commercial Flooring Specialists; St Mark‚Äôs Church; Grimsby Minster; North East Lincolnshire Council; Lincs Inspire; Wilkos; Great Grimsby Labour Party; Clintons cards;...

Name: Melanie Onn
Message: Thanks to generosity of Great Grimsby Labour Party members attending AGM tonight, we will be donating ¬£75 to the Grenfell Tower appeal

Name: Melanie Onn
Message: I'm delighted to be appointed Shadow Housing Minister. Housing is an issue which comes up again and again when I speak to people in Great Grimsby, whether it‚Äôs about empty properties, poor quality buildings, rip off letting fees for those renting privately, or the Tory Government‚Äôs cuts to social housing forcing sheltered accommodation to close. My new role will allow me to take the arguments directly to the Tory Government about their failure to build enough homes, and to make the case for proper investment in social housing. The recent tragedy at Grenfell Tower showed the importance of getting housing policy right, and the important role the opposition party has in scrutinising the government and highlighting the areas where they‚Äôre getting it wrong. Homelessness is an issue which I‚Äôve personally campaigned on since I first entered Parliament two years ago, so I‚Äôm pleased to now be in a position where I can hold the Government to account for this on a weekly basis. We‚Äôve recently...

Name: Melanie Onn
Message: Labour is calling on the government to set aside ¬£1bn to properly fund the retrofitting of sprinklers in all Council and Housing Association tower blocks across the country. We want the government to start with tower blocks that are 30 meters or higher, which is around 10 storeys, principally to make sure that there are no residents living in high rises without the added safety of sprinklers. It is vitally important to make sure that there are no Councils or Housing Associations unable to do that vital work because they don‚Äôt have enough funds. Back in 2007, when Labour was in government, we made it compulsory for all new high rise blocks to have sprinklers fitted. We are now urging this government, in light of the tragedy at Grenfell Tower - and prior to that in Lakanal House - to take on board the necessity to make sure that people living in high rises are afforded the same protections as those who are living in new build blocks. We know that there have been coroner‚Äôs reports...

Name: Melanie Onn
Message: Cllr Ray Sutton represents a massive loss from the Shoreline board. He is right to highlight that tenants voices must be heard at a board level and that tenants must have the right to vote on decisions that affect their tenancies, homes and communities. In the wake of Grenfell it is vital that tenants are at the forefront of the decisions that housing associations make. There is a real worry that the expected merger between Shoreline and Boston Mayflower will mean a move further away from the communities they were intended to serve. I recently met with the expected chair of the merged organisation and expressed my concerns about the disappearance of tenants' voices. I will continue to press Shoreline and Boston Mayflower to include tenants throughout their decision making process as part of and after their merger. http://www.grimsbytelegraph.co.uk/news/shoreline-housing-board-member-resigns-1106240

Name: Mike Freer
Message: MP Welcomes Swift Action by Barnet Council Monday, 26 June 2017 -- For Immediate Release ‚Äì Mike Freer, MP for Finchley & Golders Green, has welcomed the swift action taken by Barnet Council to investigate the cladding at three blocks in Granville Road, Finchley. Following the devastating fire at Grenfell Tower in West London, the Government have instructed Local Authorities to carry out fire safety checks on buildings covered with cladding materials. The Council have also confirmed that they will invest in upgrades to fire safety systems in high-rise tower blocks across the Barnet area. However, the Leader of Barnet Council, Cllr Richard Cornelius, has confirmed that ‚ÄúAll Barnet-owned blocks have up to date Fire Risk Assessments and comply with fire safety legislation.‚Äù There are 24 high-rise blocks in the Borough, three having been ‚Äòreclad‚Äô in 2012: Granville Point, Harpenmead Point and Templemead Point. All three were inspected on Monday 19th June and it was concluded that the...

Name: Mike Gapes
Message: I met with Electrical Safety First recently to find out more about how constituents in Ilford South can stay electrically safe at home. Electricity causes half of all fires in England‚Äôs homes. Recent tragic events at Grenfell Tower have made everyone much more aware of the risks from electrical products ‚Äì items we use unthinkingly, every day. I would like to encourage people to sign up and support this campaign by visiting www.supportsaferhomes.com:=:https://www.supportsaferhomes.com/ Electrical Safety First have also developed a range of resources to help check the safety of a property. This includes a mobile phone app, which provides a quick visual check of the electrics in a home, plus a link to find a registered electrician in your area. https://www.electricalsafetyfirst.org.uk/guides-and-advice/around-the-home/overloading-sockets/:=:https://www.electricalsafetyfirst.org.uk/errorpages/servererror/?aspxerrorpath=/guides-and-advice/around-the-home/overloading-sockets/

Name: Mims Davies
Message: Thank you for contacting me both here, on email and twitter about the truly tragic events at Grenfell Towers on Wednesday morning. Like you, I was devastated when I first heard of the tragedy that was unfolding in Kensington, and join the Prime Minister and others in giving my heartfelt condolences to the families and friends of those that lost their lives. This is a truly awful situation with much uncertainty still for many families, friends & colleagues and it is a really heartbreaking situation. The immediate focus must be to ensure that those that now find themselves homeless have shelter and support going forward, many of them having lost all of their worldly possessions. I would also like to acknowledge the amazing efforts of our emergency services, who as always went beyond the call of duty, and as a result, saved countless lives. For our part, I can assure you that this Government is fully committed to ensuring that rental properties are both safe and affordable for...

Name: Naz Shah
Message: The government is abdicating its responsibility to leaseholders like those with flats in Landmark House. Whilst Ministers pay lip service to cost recovery via other means, the reality on the ground is that developers are simply passing the cost of re-cladding on to residents. This is completely unacceptable. Leaseholders brought their homes on the understanding that these buildings were fully compliant with safety legislation. It is absolutely wrong that residents like those at Landmark House should have to pay ro remedy deficiencies in the building of which they were completely unaware.‚Äù http://www.thetelegraphandargus.co.uk/news/16227517.Bradford_flats_must_have_Grenfell-style_cladding_removed__immediately__-_MP/#comments-anchor

Name: Neil Coyle
Message: Message from PM appears to be 'the buck starts here' when it comes to #Grenfell - Govt must step in & fund sprinklers & cladding inspections

Name: Neil Coyle
Message: It has been over a month since the fire broke out and engulfed Grenfell Tower. Many are still trying to come to terms with this horrific event, in which at least 80 people lost their lives. This tragedy is incomprehensible but was also avoidable. Many are understandably angry and are seeking answers. The inquiry is underway but will take some time to provide an account of what went so tragically wrong. The Government has utterly failed to live up to its job on this issue. Theresa May offers no leadership in the past month. Councils have had their budgets axed in the last seven years but now face the huge challenge of retro-fitting sprinklers into tower blocks to make people feel safe in their own homes. The Government has refused to clarify if councils will be able to reclaim funding this measure - and Ministers still have not outlined what resources will be provided to ensure necessary fire safety inspections and improvements are undertaken. I have written a joint letter with Rt...

Message: 9 months on from the horror and tragedy of the Grenfell fire, and the Government have still not given Southwark Council a penny to fit sprinklers in tower blocks - of which Southwark has 170. Watch my question here:

Name: Neil Gray
Message: After seeing the horrific scenes in London last week, I wrote to North Lanarkshire Council's Chief Executive to get some clarity on the safety of residents of tower blocks in not only Airdrie & Shotts but North Lanarkshire in general. I am seeking assurances on the issue of cladding, which appears to have been an accelerant in the Grenfell Tower tragedy and the fire safety measures in place should, Heaven forbid, a mass evacuation be required. Finally I have requested that a letter is sent to all residents of the Council‚Äôs tower blocks to advise them of the situation regarding the general safety of their particular block. We must do all we can to ensure that NLC is managing the running of this type of accommodation appropriately with the safety of the tenants upmost on the priority list. I will post an update when NLC reply.

Name: Nic Dakin
Message: My Diary for the week ending June 18th. The absolute horror of the Grenfell Tower fire make any words empty and inadequate. I could hardly watch the devastating scenes from the catastrophe. So much pain and suffering. A manmade, seemingly preventable disaster in 21st century Britain at the heart of one of London‚Äôs richest boroughs. The agonising grief of a community let down and the amazing heroism of emergency services personnel contrasted with the flatfooted response of national and local Government. Of course everyone living in tower blocks all over the country will be anxious about their own safety now and understandably so. I was reassured to be contacted by Ongo who have the Crosby and Trent View House Flats to be told they were tacking immediate steps to reassure tenants. One of my priorities this week is to double check this. We seem to be in a time of awful events coming from nowhere with yet another suspected terrorist attack reported this morning. In these times it is...

Name: Nic Dakin
Message: Some thoughts on the State Opening of Parliament. For the first time ever I moved fast enough to get in to the House of Lords to see the Queen deliver her speech to open Parliament's session. Unusually she wore no crown or robes. This matched the cut down Queen's Speech she was reading. Just 4 pages with very little in them. Thankfully all the nonsense about creating more grammar schools, scrapping the winter fuel allowance and the triple lock or scrapping free infant school meals did not feature. Like the manifesto that hatched them these ideological ideas have been essentially binned. Indeed the Conservative's website now has a blank space where once the ill-fated manifesto with its Dementia Tax once was. So what is in the Queen's Speech? Not very much. There's a lot of welcome emphasis on taking steps to strengthen our security and to learn form the awful tragedy of Grenfell Tower so steps can be taken to ensure it doesn't happen again. So far so good but then it talks about...

Name: Nic Dakin
Message: Last month I was fortunate enough to spend four days working in Nic‚Äôs Westminster office. This was a great way to celebrate the end of exam period, whilst preparing myself for university, as my degree includes a whole year working in Parliament. Whilst I was in London I did a variety of different tasks, from simply exploring the Palace of Westminster, to carrying research tasks, to even going with Nic to a radio interview. The first two days of my visit, Nic was in the constituency which meant I was alone in the office! This allowed me to show my independence of setting myself tasks and dealing with the constant calls to the office phone! It was a great way to spend my first week of freedom from college. I also managed to get a ticket to the final PMQ‚Äôs before recess, which was a great experience to once again see Jeremy Corbyn taking control and questioning Theresa May on varying areas including Grenfell Tower. Before I left Parliament, I managed to sit in the side gallery for the...

Name: Nigel Huddleston
Message: In PMQs today, I asked the Prime Minister to confirm that it is her intention to go further than Dame Judith Hackitt's recommendations on building safety regulations and ban inflamable cladding, so that we avoid a horrific tragedy like Grenfell ever happening again. I was delighted that the Prime Minister confirmed that the Government is minded to go further than the recommendations and ban all combustible materials in cladding on high rise buildings.

Name: Nigel Huddleston

Name: Norman Lamb
Message: The Grenfell tragedy is a damning example of profit taking priority over human safety. The Government needs to ensure there are effective sanctions against those who cut corners in the pursuit of profit so that they are held to account and to act as effective deterrents. And how can we justify not giving tower block residents the same protection that hotel guests enjoy as a result of regulations requiring sprinkler systems to be installed?

Name: Oliver Dowden
Message: Spoke in the debate on the Queen‚Äôs Speech today. Used it as an opportunity to discuss how we provide more houses for our children and grandchildren, but also how we protect our green belt and get the infrastructure we need, particularly in Borehamwood. You may be interested to see my opening comments on Grenfell Tower where I also pay tribute to the excellent work done by Borehamwood residents through Borehamwood Synagogue to support victims. To watch a clip of my contribution, please follow the link below: https://goo.gl/wVFSx3:=:http://parliamentlive.tv/home/_404?aspxerrorpath=/event/index/18b1ea2c-c8a9-4314-a9cc-efbb81cc2b38

Name: Patrick Grady
Message: Since the Grenfell Tower tragedy many people have been worried about fire safety. Yesterday I spoke in the Grenfell Tower Inquiry debate, and drew attention to the importance of providing assurances to residents in Glasgow North, particularly those in multi-storey high rise buildings. I am grateful to my colleague Joanna Cherry QC MP for outlining the actions the Scottish Government have taken since the tragedy. Whilst investigations into the London fire are ongoing, it is crucial that as much support, reassurance and certainty as possible is clearly communicated. I‚Äôd like to provide a brief update here, however please visit my website for the latest comprehensive update: https://goo.gl/Na2xE6:=:https://www.patrickgrady.scot/112-scottish-government-response-on-fire-safety-2 Following the fire in London I wrote to Glasgow City Council, the Scottish Government, and to all Housing Associations in Glasgow North to seek assurances about the fire safety measures. I have now received...

Name: Paul Blomfield
Message: High rise housing and fire safety The disaster at Grenfell Tower has shocked the country. It is appalling in 21st century Britain that fire should be able to take hold and engulf a building in the way that we saw last week, with its heart-breaking consequences. Our thoughts are with the victims and their families, but we must also act quickly to ensure that it can never happen again. So I‚Äôll be joining colleagues in Parliament in pressing for an urgent review of fire safety regulations ‚Äì based on the results of a full public inquiry into the fire that must take place without delay. I arranged a meeting with Sheffield City Council yesterday to discuss the local implications. Most of the city‚Äôs high rise housing is in my constituency. I was pleased at the quick and positive response from the Council in contacting their tenants to reassure them. Although we can‚Äôt pre-judge the outcome of the inquiry, much of the attention on the Grenfell Tower fire has been on the cladding ‚Äì so it is...

Name: Paul Flynn
Message: It was Harry Jones‚Äô first meeting a councillor. He later became Sir Harry after a long and distinguished career. He told me about his astonishing experience at his first meeting. A councillor urged stopping the building of a tower block of flats at Julian‚Äôs, filling the void with concrete and inscribing on the side of the building, ‚ÄòThis giant tombstone was erected in dishonourable memory of the failed concept of hi-rise living.‚Äô That was in about 1976. My remarks were part of a many-faceted campaign against experimental housing. My simple concept was that the evolved model of two ‚Äìstoreys, upstairs for sleeping to protect us from the sabre-toothed tigers, downstairs for living plus two enclosed areas, one in front for decorative use, one behind for utilitarian use. The further the ambitious, creative, imaginative, phallus building architects strayed from the ideal the worst the results became for satisfying habitation. I was also campaigning long before Thatcher for tenants to...

Name: Paul Scully
Message: I'm in regular contact with residents of Chaucer House and Balaam House to work on their concerns about fire safety post-Grenfell. Involving residents at every stage is so important and so I asked the Secretary of State for Housing, Communities and Local Government what measures the government were taking to ensure they do exactly this for the survivors and the families of the Grenfell Tower tragedy.

Name: Paul Scully
Message: Yesterday was a tough but rewarding day. I led the debate in Parliament about the #Grenfell Inquiry. Grenfell Speaks were out in Parliament Square beforehand to express their frustration, despair and anger and of course to pay tribute to the 72 victims of the fire. Reading some of the pen sketches about the victims in preparation for my speech was so moving and really hammered home the need to ensure that every part of the rehousing and recovery process is people-centred. I'm really grateful to Grenfell United and members of the community to take the time to speak to me and I value their dignified determination and resolve.

Name: Paul Scully
Message: In my opening speech during the Grenfell Inquiry debate, I read out the names of the 72 victims of the fire to show that this isn't about process but people. The Prime Minister has shown that she is listening by appointing two additional panel members but we need to do more to meet the needs and expectations of Grenfell Speaks. They feel ignored, forgotten about and that the establishment treats them as a bother. It isn't the case but the belief is totally understandable. The government at every level, national and local, needs to continue to work hard to ensure that the survivors can get answers, start to rebuild their lives and see justice done.

Name: Paul Scully
Message: Yesterday I had another opportunity to pay tribute to the Grenfell Speaks campaigners and talk about the need to ensure we act, not just say soothing words, to ensure the community get the housing and the justice they need and deserve.

Name: Paul Scully

Name: Paul Scully
Message: Very emotional day yesterday opening the debate on the #Grenfell Inquiry. I was proud to give @GrenfellUnited @grenfellspeaks & the community a voice within Parliament whilst they made their voice heard outside. My speech - http://bit.ly/2IpgFrF https://t.co/BVItEJa8dd

Name: Paula Sherriff
Message: Our public sector heroes work tirelessly for us in some of the most difficult circumstances, often placing their lives on the line for us. We've seen this heroism on display over the last few months. For just one example, who could forget the footage of those brave fire fighters who ran into danger at Grenfell Tower, putting their own lives at risk, hoping to save others? We've seen attacks on paramedics, nurses, police officers and other emergency service workers increase over the last few years and this is, quite frankly, a shocking thing to read about. According to the Royal College of Nursing, 28 per cent of NHS staff had experienced physical abuse in the previous 12 months and seven in ten had experienced verbal abuse. The Police Federation for England and Wales' figures estimate an attack on a police officer every four minutes. This is why I am backing calls from the fantastic Labour MPs Chris Bryant and Holly Lynch to make sentences for attacks on emergency service workers...

Name: Penny Mordaunt
Message: One of the things that gives people such comfort in the aftermath of tragedy is how a community responded. Whether it is in donating clothes and food to those who have lost everything, taxi drivers not charging to take people home, or people supporting or volunteering to help. We have seen this after the recent terror attacks and the horrific fire at Grenfell Tower. People feel their common humanity and community strongly. People do it because they care, and also because they do not like to feel they cannot help, they want to wrap their arms around those who are suffering, they want to meet that unmet need. Today there is something you can do to help people in this way. It might help in the wake of the next attack, or incident, or it might help a new born baby with sickle cell, or a patient for surgery. You won't know, but you will make a massive difference. Please decide to register and give blood. It's National Blood Week from 19th- 25th June, celebrating the 900,000 donors who...

Name: Peter Grant
Message: Procedural palaver in the house of commons this afternoon when the opposition kicked up about the fact that a major announcement over the weekend about the HS2 rail project was not being followed up with a ministerial statement. It's now been decided that there will be a statement - starting after any votes that are needed beginning at 10pm. The votes could easily last for an hour. Meanwhile we've had an "England & Wales only" statement on school funding which went on for nearly 2 hours and we're about to have a debate on the mess the government are making of timetabling parliamentary business. https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm201719/cmagenda/ob170717.htm

Name: Peter Grant
Message: Today's business in the house of commons. As usual on the first day back after a recess there's a lot of urgent business that wasn't on the order paper. There's an urgent statement on the persecution of Rohingya Muslims in Burma, then at about 4.20 we'll get an update on the Brexit negotiations. I'll be responding to this on behalf of the SNP. We then have urgent statements on Grenfell Tower and on North Korea and a request from the SNP's Ian Blackford for an urgent debate on the government's failure to follow its own rules on consulting with the devolved governments over Brexit. Current predictions are that we'll get to the main "business of the day" at about 7.30pm. https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm201719/cmagenda/ob170905.htm

Name: Peter Kyle
Message: Seeing the news about Grenfell Tower disaster has been shocking and I was immediately in touch with MP's in London to see if there is anything our community could do to offer support. As you can see from the news there is nothing needed from us at this time, but that might change so I'm in touch on that front so I will keep you updated. Thank you to those who have been in touch with me offering help, I have passed our community's sympathy and willingness to support on and will continue to monitor the need for help. I have also been in touch with our council regarding our high rise housing. I have been assured that each one is checked for fire safety every year, that one was fitted with a sprinkler system recently and two more are scheduled for similar fitting. The council is also reviewing the safety of our high rise units and the use of cladding. I am remaining in very close touch with them in the coming days to ensure that as lessons from this horrible disaster emerge that we...

Name: Rachel Reeves
Message: A number of residents have been in touch with me about their concerns over the last few days. Please see below some important information from Leeds City Council.

Name: Rachel Reeves
Message: Today in Parliament I urged the Prime Minister to provide funds to local authorities to ensure high rise flats are safe and secure. Leeds City Council have responded swiftly to concerns following the Grenfell Tower disaster - communicating with tenants and residents and testing all cladding - and assuring people that no blocks in Leeds use the cladding used in Kensington. However, LCC and many other local authorities need funds to pay for the installation of sprinkler systems, fire alarms and suitable cladding in all high rise flats - including the 26 blocks in Leeds West. The Government must act and provide the funds so that everyone can feel safe in their homes. I will continue to put pressure on the Government to provide these resources as a matter of urgency.

Name: Rachel Reeves
Message: I have written about safety in high rise blocks ...

Name: Rachel Reeves
Message: Just after I became MP for Leeds West seven years ago, I surveyed local council high-rises and found many residents were unhappy. Often, the lifts did not work and there were complaints about uncleared rubbish, anti-social behaviour and the failure to carry out repairs swiftly. I campaigned for the blocks to be taken back under the control of Leeds City Council and I am glad that happened. It is a change that has undoubtedly improved the situation for tenants. However, the council‚Äôs work has been made harder due to relentless budget cuts under the Tories. Since 2010, the Tories have cut Leeds City Council‚Äôs core funding by ¬£214m. Despite those cuts, the council is working hard to reassure people in high rises. The council is desperate to do more but simply does not have the money. Theresa May could solve that by releasing the ¬£30m needed to install sprinklers....

Name: Richard Burgon
Message: üíöüíö Great news!üíöüíö The petition on the Grenfell Inquiry has now passed 100,000 signatures thanks to great work this week by Stormzy, Grenfell United and others. Survivors of the Grenfell fire and their bereaved families are demanding a broad-based panel to ensure those affected have full confidence in the Inquiry. I am proud that Labour has supported this demand from the outset. Sadly, the Conservative Prime Minister has constantly refused to use her powers to ensure this happens. Now, thanks to the public, Parliament will debate it. You can still show your support by signing the petition below. https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/206722

Message: Thanks to great work of @GrenfellUnited @Stormzy1 and others we now have over 100k signatures for a broad panel at the Grenfell Inquiry. Name: Richard Burgon
Message: On Monday Parliament will finally debate the Grenfell Inquiry Panel. The Prime Minister should listen to the survivors, bereaved families and more than 150,000 members of the public and appoint a panel with diverse experience and expertise.

Name: Richard Burgon
Message: There will be a Written Ministerial Statement by the Prime Minister today on Grenfell. Let‚Äôs hope that - ahead of Monday's parliamentary debate - it‚Äôs about creating an independent decision-making panel for the Inquiry. If not, Labour will force a vote on this next week.

Name: Richard Burgon
Message: The decision to finally grant a panel in the Grenfell Inquiry is testimony to the campaign by the bereaved families and the survivors - and to the overwhelming public support they attracted. But after everything they have been through, the bereaved families and the survivors should never have had to wage this campaign. The demand for a panel was always about ensuring the trust of the community in the Inquiry and a panel should have been delivered from the start. For the Grenfell Inquiry to deliver truth and justice, it must always have the full confidence of the bereaved families and survivors and it is essential that, going forward, all their other demands are properly met.

Name: Richard Burgon
Message: Almost a year since the Grenfell Inquiry was announced, Theresa May has finally acted on the survivors' call for a panel of experts to be appointed. No-one should be forced to petition for justice. Survivors' voices must be heard throughout this Inquiry.

Name: Richard Burgon
Message: The PM has finally agreed to the call from survivors and bereaved families for a panel of experts to be appointed. This result is a testament to the tenacity of survivors and families. But they shouldn‚Äôt have had to petition and lobby to get this. They deserve justice.

Name: Richard Burgon
Message: The decision to finally grant a panel in the Grenfell Inquiry is a step forward and a result of the tenacious campaigning by survivors and bereaved family members But lots of questions remain unanswered. For example, why is the panel only going to sit in Phase 2 of the Inquiry? Where are we with the second demand in the public petition about survivors' lawyers having all the evidence from the start and being able to cross-examine the witnesses, as happened in the Lawrence Inquiry? What mechanisms are there to guarantee the ongoing confidence of survivors and bereaved family members in the Inquiry? For the Grenfell Inquiry to deliver truth and justice, it must always have the full confidence of the bereaved families and survivors. At tomorrow‚Äôs Grenfell Inquiry parliamentary debate we need greater clarity from the Government, not the delays and obfuscations we have had over recent months.

Name: Richard Burgon
Message: Today I attended the Grenfell Inquiry and heard from lawyers representing the bereaved families and survivors. One of the lawyers called for changes to the Terms of Reference so that they also include whether the treatment of residents and survivors, based on their race, religion and social class played any part in the events that led to the fire. This is an entirely just request and something that the Prime Minister could - and should - ensure under the powers she has under 2005 Inquiries Act. Earlier, another lawyer said that a number of firms involved in refurbishing Grenfell Tower have showed ‚Äúno desire to assist the inquiry‚Äù and that this silence ‚Äúdeprives the families of the degree of resolution and understanding to which they are entitled and has only served to increase their pain and uncertainty." That is why the Prime Minister should now enact the Hillsborough Law. After the conclusion of the Hillsborough Inquest, the families called for a lasting legacy to prevent other...

Name: Richard Burgon
Message: Today the Grenfell Inquiry heard that a number of firms involved in the refurbishments have showed ‚Äúno desire to assist the inquiry‚Äù. Disgraceful. That's why the PM should now enact the Hillsborough Law to ensure such companies must act in the public interest and with candour. https://t.co/lr03MsRL2I

Name: Richard Graham
Message: A new term starts: walking with Dr Caroline Johnson to the Lords for the authorisation of a new Parliament. The Queen's Speech setting out the legislative programme is on Wednesday. I expect a Mental Health Bill & work towards resolving the thorny question of social care - and that much of the focus of other legislation will be around leaving the EU. The dynamics of every Parliament change. This one has more diversity and (I anticipate) less stridency from the SNP: and perhaps more co-operation across party boundaries on selected issues, which I'd welcome. Meanwhile we await the investigation into the awful Grenfell Tower inferno, and both that and the tasering and arrest of a man with a knife outside Parliament reminds us that life is to be treasured.

Name: Richard Graham
Message: An outstanding response to the Grenfell Tower inferno, alongside their visits to buildings and resident reassurance, from Glos Fire. Huge thanks.

Name: Richard Graham
Message: This is the third time I've sworn allegiance to our Queen on becoming MP. The words are historic: the commitment is as valid as it ever was. It's a bit like prayers at the beginning of every day in Parliament, where we promise not to '...lead the nation through love of power, desire to please or unworthy ideals but laying aside all private interests and prejudices...seek to improve the condition of all mankind'. These are good values for a politician to hold dear, and I'll go on doing so. Now for Wednesday and the Queen's Speech (programme of new laws). But in between my swearing in and today came the ghastly inferno at Grenfell Tower and yesterday's horrible attack outside Finsbury Park Mosque. Both of these have caused me to call our Fire Service and Constabulary (respectively) to agree immediate and longer term steps to reassure constituents. This is a key responsibility.

Name: Robin Walker
Message: Worcester‚Äôs MP, Robin Walker, has expressed his condolences to all those affected by the fire at Grenfell Tower in West London. In the early hours of this morning (14th June) over 200 fire fighters from London Fire Brigade attended a rapidly developing incident at the 24-storey tower block in North Kensington. The fire was quickly declared a major incident and crews wearing breathing apparatus have been working in extremely difficult conditions to rescue people and bring this major fire under control. This morning Robin spoke with Fire Safety Officers at Hereford and Worcester Fire and Rescue Service to seek reassurances on the assessments that have been made of the safety of tower blocks in Worcester, specifically the Severn House, Cripplegate House and Henwick House blocks in St Johns. Speaking to Mark Preece, Head of Community Risk and Training at Hereford and Worcester Fire and Rescue Service, Robin received assurances that extensive fire safety checks and drills have been...
