Name: Rosie Winterton
Message: The tragedy at Grenfell Tower must never be repeated and I welcome the announcement of a public inquiry. Today I visited Silverwood House alongside Cllr John McHale, Deputy Mayor Glyn Jones, Mick Werritt - Director of Property Services and Paul Tannay - Chief Executive of St Leger Homes to gain a better insight into the precautionary work which is taking place, including the removal of some decorative capping on the building. I also met with local residents Sue Wood and Sue O‚ÄôConnor, who are part of the Balby Bridge TARA, to discuss any concerns residents may have. The proactive approach St Leger Homes and Doncaster Council have and are continuing to undertake is encouraging. Local residents old me that they were extremely satisfied by the way that information had been communicated to them by all concerned and I am assured by St Leger Homes that this will continue to be the case. Should anyone have any queries regarding this matter then I have included some useful links below;...

Name: Royston Smith
Message: In recent days, I have been contacted by a number of residents, some by email and others on Facebook, in relation to an Independent article from last year linked to the 2016 Housing and Planning Act. The tragic incident at Grenfell is in all of our minds currently and all of my thoughts go out to those involved, the victims and their families. Without question, what unfolded at Grenfell should never have happened and a comprehensive review and investigation is needed to understand what went on and lessons will need to be learned. Following this incident, I have been surprised by the immediate move by some to politicise this terrible incident and the lives lost. Many people have linked a parliamentary vote in 2016, which I voted on, as an indication of blame for Grenfell. The Independent who published this article last year, have confirmed in a subsequent article yesterday, that the vote on an amendment in 2016 as part of the Housing and Planning Act, would have had no impact on...

Name: Royston Smith
Message: Yesterday I spoke in the Grenfell Fire Debate in Parliament. I am concerned that Southampton City Council failed to act to retrofit sprinklers to Shirley Towers, Sturminster House and Albion Towers in Southampton after the Shirley Towers tragedy. Over two years after they promised to do the work and allocated the funds, they have only just begun to install them on Albion Towers now.

Name: Rushanara Ali
Message: At yesterday‚Äôs hearing of the Treasury Select Committee, I called on the Chancellor to ensure that housing associations and councils are sufficiently funded to complete safety repairs, and that private landlords fulfil their duty of maintaining safe properties for tenants. Nearly a year after the Grenfell tragedy, only seven out of 160 social housing blocks with flammable cladding similar to that used in the Grenfell tower block, have been replaced. Residents should not have to wait years for vitally needed repairs. Urgent action is needed to support local councils and residents in funding and accessing vital safety measures and repairs. Some housing associations do not have sufficient funds to do the work, whilst others are having problems accessing the money. Currently the government is shirking responsibility and much more needs be done to speed up the repairs process. Residents in privately rented blocks as well as social housing feel let down by the government. Residents and...

Name: Ruth Cadbury
Message: Today I spoke in the House of Commons debate on the Grenfell Tower inquiry. Important points were raised and questions asked of Ministers on issues that the Government must address. All residents of tower blocks deserve reassurance, so that they can live and sleep in peace. Poor communities and those in housing need require a Government who no longer ignore them, cut vital services, and ignore the conclusions of public inquiries, and a Government who invest in adequate, good-quality, truly affordable housing. For the full debate please go to parliamentlive.uk

Name: Ruth Cadbury
Message: Grenfell Survivors telling their story in Parliament now. Need; consistent key workers, ownership of responsibility by Govt & RBK&C, review of Building Regs as recommended after Lakenhall inquiry, Fire Inspectors to be brought back into Fire Service https://t.co/ofCA3dQKxl

Name: Ruth Cadbury
Message: Today marks 6 months after the Grenfell Tower fire. 'It is illegal for children to live in bed and breakfast accommodation for more than six weeks, yet many Grenfell victims have been staying in bed and breakfast hotels for the entire six-month period since the fire.' https://twitter.com/Independent/status/940472537263226880

Name: Ruth Cadbury
Message: Eleven months after the Grenfell Tower fire, over 300 buildings have been found with dangerous cladding but only seven have been identified as having had it removed and replaced. Labour demands a complete overhaul of the discredited system of building safety checks and controls. In addition to current legal sanctions including fines and banning orders, Labour wants to see a new back-stop power for councils to seek court approval for the confiscation of any private block which is putting lives at risk because of dangerous cladding, and which the owner is refusing to fix.

Name: Ruth Cadbury
Message: Not a lack of interest in housing legal aid from @UKLabour colleagues, but a busy day in Parliament especially the #Grenfell debate in the main chamber going on at the same time https://twitter.com/monidipafouzder/status/996750189997281280

Name: Ruth Smeeth
Message: My colleague Gareth Snell MP and I wrote to Stoke-on-Trent City Council last week to request further information about when spirnklers would be fitted in high rises across the city. As the tragic events at Grenfell have reminded us, we need to do everything possible to keep people safe in their homes.

Name: Sadiq Khan
Message: I'm truly devastated to see the horrific scenes of the major fire at Grenfell Tower in Kensington. I have been in constant contact throughout the night with the Commissioner of the London Fire Brigade, Dany Cotton, who has been at the scene. More than 250 firefighters are at the scene and there have been more than 100 medics in attendance, as well as 100 police officers. I want to thank our incredible firefighters and emergency services for their immense courage, dedication and professionalism. My heart goes out to everyone affected. I am sad to confirm that we now know there have been fatalities and more than fifty people have been taken to hospitals including Royal Free, King‚Äôs, St Thomas‚Äôs, St Mary‚Äôs and Chelsea and Westminster to be treated for injuries. The fire service is dealing with a rapidly changing situation and these numbers are likely to rise. The Hammersmith & City and Circle lines are currently suspended between Hammersmith and Edgware Road and the A40 is closed in...

Name: Sadiq Khan
Message: Sadly, it has been confirmed that 12 people are now known to have died as a result of the horrific fire at Grenfell Tower ‚Äì a figure which I am afraid is expected to increase. We also know that a further 78 people have been taken to six hospitals across the capital. The loved ones of the victims and everyone affected are in my thoughts. I have been in talks with Government ministers, including the Secretary of State for Communities and Local Government, this afternoon, and I am working hard with them and of course with our emergency services on the response to the fire. I raised the issue of checks on other tower blocks which have been going through similar refurbishment programmes to Grenfell House, and I welcome that ministers have said checks will now be carried out. Earlier today, I visited the scene at Grenfell Tower, where I met the brave firefighters and emergency services staff who have been working around the clock, as well as local residents who are pulling together to...

Name: Sadiq Khan
Message: If you would like to donate to the Grenfell Tower appeal to support those affected, or volunteer to help, you can find more information here: http://www.rbkc.gov.uk/newsroom/all-council-statements/fire-grenfell-tower:=:https://www.rbkc.gov.uk/newsroom/all-council-statements/fire-grenfell-tower

Name: Sadiq Khan
Message: UPDATE: 11:46 This morning, the Metropolitan Police have confirmed that sadly 17 people are now known to have died in the terrible fire at Grenfell Tower. Any family & friends concerned about their loved ones please contact the Casualty Bureau on 0800 0961 233. I know all Londoners will continue to hold all the victims of this tragedy in our thoughts. You can find information on how to donate or volunteer to support here https://www.rbkc.gov.uk/newsroom/all-council-statements/fire-grenfell-tower ----------- UPDATE: 18:56 Sadly, it has been confirmed that 12 people are now known to have died as a result of the horrific fire at Grenfell Tower ‚Äì a figure which I am afraid is expected to increase. We also know that a further 78 people have been taken to six hospitals across the capital. The loved ones of the victims and everyone affected are in my thoughts. I have been in talks with Government ministers, including the Secretary of State for Communities and Local Government, this...

Name: Sadiq Khan
Message: The Metropolitan Police have confirmed that tragically 17 people are now known to have died in the terrible fire at Grenfell Tower. Sadly this figure is likely to rise, and my thoughts and prayers remain with all those affected. Today the fire has been brought under control and the fire brigade and our other emergency services are continuing to work heroically. The operation is now shifting from the search and rescue phase to the recovery phase. Under these circumstances the full scale of the tragedy is becoming clear and there are pressing questions, which demand urgent answers. That's why I've demanded a full, independent public inquiry into the fire at Grenfell Tower. In light of concerns about the safety of other tower blocks that have been similarly refurbished the inquiry needs to produce an interim report by the end of this summer at the latest. Meanwhile, any family and friends concerned about their loved ones should contact the Casualty Bureau on 0800 0961 233.

Name: Sadiq Khan
Message: I spent this afternoon in North Kensington. I‚Äôve been listening to local residents around Grenfell Tower ‚Äì at the Westway Sports Centre which is acting as a refuge for those affected, at Notting Hill Methodist Church, where food, clothing and bedding are being collected and distributed and speaking to people on the local roads and estates. This is an extremely tight-knit community and local people are understandably distraught at what has happened, and increasingly frustrated and angry that their concerns were simply ignored for so long. Many have loved ones who are still unaccounted for. They are looking for answers to their legitimate questions about why this has happened, why they weren‚Äôt listened to and how they are going to get their lives back on track. I grew up on a similar council estate in South London and this could easily have been my family, my friends and my community. I share their anger and concern. This community deserves answers ‚Äì and quickly. We cannot wait years...

Name: Sadiq Khan
Message: My letter to the Prime Minister, demanding answers, action and justice for those affected by the #GrenfellTower fire. Dear Prime Minister, I spent several hours yesterday talking to local residents around Grenfell Tower. These were difficult conversations with a tight-knit community that is understandably distraught, frustrated and increasingly angry. They feel the Government and local council haven‚Äôt done enough to help them in the aftermath of this horrific incident, or to provide answers to their increasingly urgent questions. I promised the local community that I would fight for them to get the support and answers they deserve as quickly as possible. I am therefore writing to you today to set out the action that I believe the Government needs to take, as a matter of urgency. Victim support and information The local community feels their grief has been made worse by the lack of information about their missing family members and friends. They are fully aware of the true scale of...

Name: Sadiq Khan
Message: Today I attended the Government's Taskforce on the tragic fire at Grenfell House this week, chaired by the Prime Minister. This week I witnessed first-hand in Kensington the justifiable anger of the local community, and spent time talking with and listening to local residents affected. Today was a crucial opportunity for me to make clear to the Government what the community have told me they need, both right now and in the longer term as they recover from this devastating fire. I made a number of points at the meeting and have highlighted below the five main points: Firstly - at the meeting I raised the need for clearer direction on the ground for those affected of how and where they can access support services, ranging from housing and financial support to counselling. This means highly visibly expert people in the community helping local residents access help. There must be better outreach work. Secondly, I stressed just how crucial it is the rehousing efforts are speeded up and...

Name: Sadiq Khan
Message: We owe it to the Grenfell Tower victims to establish the full truth. As Mayor, I will fight with every fibre of my being to make sure justice is delivered. http://bit.ly/2sGCmzg:=:https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2017/jun/18/sadiq-khan-grenfell-tower-tragedy-establish-full-truth

Name: Sadiq Khan
Message: As Mayor, I have been in close contact with London Fire Commissioner Dany Cotton since the early hours of Wednesday morning. The bravery, leadership and determination she has shown has been inspiring. #GrenfellTower https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2017/jun/17/london-fire-brigade-dany-cotton-grenfell-tower?CMP=twt_gu

Name: Sadiq Khan
Message: The community response in #FinsburyPark and #GrenfellTower shows where London can find its strength. https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2017/jun/19/finsbury-park-imam-london-terrorist-attacks-grenfell-tower-fire-sadiq-khan

Name: Sadiq Khan
Message: This afternoon I attended the Government task force overseeing the response to the tragic Grenfell Tower fire. I've promised to fight for the local community to get the answers and support they desperately need, and raised a number of the concerns local residents have shared with me. I have received assurances that support for local residents is starting to improve. The first emergency payments have been made to residents of the tower. And the first housing offers have been made so that residents can stay in a proper local home while permanent homes are secured by the Government. However, the response still needs to be better, faster and communicated more effectively. It is not good enough to assume grief stricken residents will be able to navigate the system to get help. To compliment the officers doing outreach in the Community I've offered for Team London - the volunteer programme I control - to help provide volunteers on the ground and officials are working on this tonight....

Name: Sadiq Khan
Message: My letter to the Prime Minister, demanding that residents are given a say in the Grenfell Tower public inquiry from day one so that it best serves justice and maintains the confidence of the community. Dear Prime Minister, The devastating fire that tore through Grenfell Tower on 14 June 2017 has shocked the nation. Survivors, local residents and the whole country rightly want answers on what caused the fire, and what must be done to prevent a repeat. That is why I welcome your decision to hold a Public Inquiry into the fire, as this offers the best opportunity to get to the truth. General Conduct of the Inquiry I am writing to you in advance of any decision on the Terms of Reference for the Inquiry in order to contribute my views on how I believe the Inquiry should be conducted if it is to best serve justice, and maintain the confidence of the community. As you will be aware, there is considerable mistrust and anger amongst the community, particularly directed towards those in...

Name: Sadiq Khan
Message: Today I've written to the Prime Minister, making clear that local residents and the community at #GrenfellTower must be given a say in the Public Inquiry from day one. http://www.standard.co.uk/news/london/sadiq-khan-residents-must-have-their-say-in-grenfell-tower-inquiry-a3568771.html

Name: Sadiq Khan
Message: After the terrible attacks in London over recent months, I'm pleased that today's Queen's Speech includes a commitment to create a new commission for countering extremism - and I will work with the Government to design a new strategy to root out once and for all extremism in all its forms from our city. However, the Government's review of national counter-terrorism strategy, also announced today, must include new spending plans to fully fund London's police force in the light of the increased threats we clearly face. The Government today confirmed plans to hold a full public inquiry into the tragic fire at Grenfell Tower. I've written to the Prime Minister to ensure that the inquiry is fully independent, that local people have their say in the terms of reference and have their full legal costs covered - with the best possible legal representation. I will continue to fight for the local community in North Kensington to get the answers and support they deserve. I'm deeply...

Name: Sadiq Khan
Message: I'm calling on the Government to urgently grant a right to remain in the UK, on compassionate grounds, to all #GrenfellTower residents who's immigration status is uncertain. https://t.co/ql3O2qAWSV?

Name: Sadiq Khan
Message: The thoughts and prayers of Londoners across our city are with the family of Mohammad Alhajali today. https://t.co/IvzIlJw4JE

Name: Sadiq Khan
Message: Today I met with London Fire Brigade Commissioner Dany Cotton and officers who took calls during the Grenfell Tower fire. On behalf of all Londoners, I expressed my deepest gratitude for their incredible response and for continuing to work bravely and tirelessly to keep our city safe.

Name: Sadiq Khan
Message: Thank you to the North Kensington community for inviting me to attend Eid prayers alongside them at Al Manar Mosque this morning. Normally this is a huge celebration - but for the community here today is a sombre day. In the wake of the horrific Grenfell Tower fire, this Mosque was used as a donation and volunteer centre. Worshippers were some of the first on the scene and provided shelter and support to those affected by the fire. What I have seen first-hand from this community has been incredible generosity and unity - and I wish everyone here Eid Mubarak.

Name: Sadiq Khan
Message: From churches to mosques, thank you to all faith communities in North Kensington who have come together to provide help and assistance to those affected by the terrible fire at Grenfell Tower. Your strength, courage and kindness is inspiring - and demonstrates the best of our great city.

Name: Sadiq Khan
Message: This afternoon I met with the Commissioner of the London Fire Brigade, Dany Cotton, and the Chair of the London Fire Authority, Fiona Twycross, to discuss what extra specialist equipment and support the Fire Service might require to keep the capital safe in the wake of the devastating Grenfell Tower fire. I've asked the Commissioner to report back with a review of the Brigade's requirements as soon as possible. The ferocity of the fire at Grenfell Tower shocked the entire country, and the Prime Minister has announced there will be a Public Inquiry. But it is crucial that any lessons are learned and taken on board as soon as possible. This was the largest and most challenging fire we have seen in this country for decades. With so many tall buildings in our city the public need to have confidence that they will be kept safe. Nobody can fail to have been inspired by the selfless bravery of the firefighters who risked their lives to save others. I am determined to ensure that they have...

Name: Sadiq Khan
Message: It's crucial that the Public Inquiry into the devastating Grenfell Tower fire starts as quickly as possible, so survivors and families of victims can start getting answers and the process of getting justice can begin. I promised the community in North Kensington that I would help them get the answers they deserve. Sir Martin Moore-Bick must ensure that the residents and local community are properly consulted on the Terms of Reference of the Inquiry, that they can participate throughout with their legal costs fully covered, that it looks at all of the issues relating to this terrible fire and wider issues too. An interim report should be published over the summer, so that we can start to get urgent answers to the many issues arising out of this tragedy. http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-40438701

Name: Sadiq Khan
Message: It's clear K&C council not fit for purpose. Govt must step in now & ensure leadership that all residents can trust. http://www.standard.co.uk/news/politics/kensington-council-boss-nicholas-pagetbrown-faces-growing-pressure-to-quit-over-grenfell-a3576841.html

Name: Sadiq Khan
Message: Twelve years ago, our city suffered a cowardly and barbaric terrorist attack. Four co-ordinated suicide bombings across London‚Äôs transport network killed 52 people and injured over 700. We will never forget those who lost their lives on 7/7 ‚Äì and we honour them again today and they will always remain in our hearts. As well as grieving those we have lost, we also pay tribute to the heroic efforts of our emergency services and transport colleagues on that darkest of days. Our firefighters, paramedics, police and public transport staff fought to save lives in the most horrific and harrowing of circumstances. And our first responders showed tremendous bravery, running towards danger whilst directing others to safety. The way our city stood together in the aftermath of the 7/7 attacks inspired the world. When Londoners face adversity, we always pull together. We stand up for our values and our way of life. And we have shown this again during the difficult times our city has faced in...

Name: Sadiq Khan
Message: Notting Hill Carnival is a firm London tradition and incredibly important to the local community. It should not be moved. http://www.standard.co.uk/news/london/notting-hill-carnival-minster-for-london-calls-on-sadiq-khan-to-move-festival-away-from-grenfell-a3582226.html

Name: Sadiq Khan
Message: Notting Hill Carnival is a London tradition & incredibly important to the local community. It should not be moved. https://t.co/l7p8DfuupS:=:https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2017/jul/07/sadiq-khan-rejects-call-to-move-notting-hill-carnival-after-grenfell-fire

Name: Sadiq Khan
Message: Four weeks on, the Grenfell Tower tragedy is still fresh in our minds. We will never forget the victims who lost their lives, and now more than ever, we must do everything possible to support the local community and to ensure justice is done. I have visited the tight knit community in North Kensington on many occasions since the night of this horrific fire. Today I met again with a number of residents and voluntary organisations who have been working so hard to provide the support needed by survivors and their families over the last 4 weeks. A number of concerns were raised with me, which as Mayor, I will take forward with the appropriate bodies. Many in the local community are grieving and suffering from terrible trauma. They are trying to come to terms with this terrible fire, but four weeks on they are still frustrated and angry about how they continue to be treated - I share their anger and frustration. Four weeks on, the Government and the local authority are still not giving...

Name: Sadiq Khan
Message: Londoners will feel let down by the Government on this vital issue of fire equipment funding. Without the additional funding we need from Government to act on the advice of the London Fire Commissioner, London will face very serious difficulties in maintaining and improving the way the London Fire Brigade protects our city. https://www.standard.co.uk/news/london/mayor-sadiq-khan-says-london-let-down-by-governments-refusal-to-fund-fire-equipment-a3609091.html

Name: Sadiq Khan
Message: Londoners will feel let down by the Government's decision to refuse my request for fire equipment funding. https://t.co/ygnmkytfwY:=:https://www.standard.co.uk/news/london/mayor-sadiq-khan-says-london-let-down-by-governments-refusal-to-fund-fire-equipment-a3609091.html

Name: Sadiq Khan
Message: In the wake of the horrific fire at Grenfell Tower, I promised I would fight for justice on behalf of all those affected by this devastating tragedy. That is why I called for a Public Inquiry, and made clear that the Judge must listen to local residents about what they want from it. I urge Sir Martin Moore-Bick to do everything in his power to deliver the inquiry‚Äôs interim report as quickly as possible. Easter is a long way off and he should do his best to publish interim findings well before then. Residents urgently need answers, and more lives are potentially at risk if we do not act quickly to establish the facts. We need to ensure such a tragedy can never happen again. There are some key concerns not covered by these Terms of Reference. It is vital that the wider questions around social housing are answered if the community‚Äôs shattered confidence is to be restored, alongside an investigation into our ability to respond to emergencies and the fire risk from household appliances....

Name: Sadiq Khan
Message: The Government‚Äôs delay in implementing these recommendations is simply inexcusable. http://www.mirror.co.uk/news/politics/theresa-urged-speed-up-action-11020347

Name: Sadiq Khan
Message: Notting Hill Carnival is one of the most important events in London‚Äôs cultural calendar, and is a unifying and positive force in this city ‚Äì bringing people together to celebrate the very best of London and its amazing diversity. I was honoured to take part in the opening ceremony this morning, which started the world-famous carnival parade, and to remember all those affected by the devastating fire at Grenfell Tower which has left a tight-knit community in sorrow and mourning. The families of those who tragically lost their lives ‚Äì many of whom are here today - made it clear they want to use this occasion as a way for people to support the community and to come together, honour, and celebrate the lives of their loved ones and that is exactly what we did today. A million people are expected in this small pocket of West London this weekend, and it will be busy. We‚Äôre already off to a great start and can expect some fantastic dancing, music and street food over the next two days. So...

Name: Sadiq Khan
Message: Londoners from across our city are coming together to honour the #GrenfellTower victims here at #NottingHillCarnival. https://t.co/cjTdTyIGG1:=:http://www.mirror.co.uk/news/politics/dozens-white-doves-released-memory-11065348.amp

Name: Sadiq Khan
Message: Residents must be at the heart of decision-making on social housing in the aftermath of the Grenfell Tower fire. I‚Äôve written to the Prime Minister, calling on her to work with me and residents to develop a package of measures that guarantee they have a much stronger voice. https://www.standard.co.uk/news/mayor/sadiq-khan-demands-government-creates-first-social-housing-tsar-after-grenfell-a3624736.html

Name: Sadiq Khan
Message: Residents must be at the heart of decision-making on social housing in the aftermath of the #GrenfellTower fire. https://t.co/QoPuTeow8I:=:https://www.standard.co.uk/news/mayor/sadiq-khan-demands-government-creates-first-social-housing-tsar-after-grenfell-a3624736.html

Name: Sadiq Khan
Message: Residents must be at the heart of decision-making on social housing after the #GrenfellTower fire. https://www.standard.co.uk/news/mayor/sadiq-khan-demands-government-creates-first-social-housing-tsar-after-grenfell-a3624736.html

Name: Sadiq Khan
Message: One hundred days on from the horrific #GrenfellTower fire, I am more determined than ever to ensure we see justice for the Grenfell community. http://www.mirror.co.uk/news/politics/100-days-after-grenfell-must-11218032

Name: Sadiq Khan
Message: In the face of a growing threat to London and other global cities, I'm doing everything in my power to ensure our capital is as prepared as possible to respond to terrorism. Our police officers and emergency services do a fantastic job, working tirelessly every day to keep us safe. That's why one of the first things I did once becoming Mayor was to ask Lord Toby Harris to undertake an independent review of London's preparedness to respond to the threat of terrorism. We've worked extremely hard together to deliver on the recommendations and to make London safer, whilst also coping with four horrific terror attacks and the tragic fire at Grenfell Tower this year. One year on, we have implemented more than two thirds of Lord Harris‚Äôs recommendations, but there is still work to do. The Government needs to put Londoners' safety first: it must step up, stop dragging its feet and take urgent action on the remaining recommendations. They must also provide the proper funding our police and...

Name: Sadiq Khan
Message: Keeping Londoners safe is my top priority - and it's absolutely essential that we learn every lesson we can from the terrible Grenfell tragedy. My draft London Plan, published this week, will set out the highest standards for fire safety. http://www.mirror.co.uk/news/politics/new-council-tower-blocks-london-11587601.amp

Name: Sadiq Khan
Message: The tragic fire at Grenfell Tower took a terrible toll on the local community. Pleased we‚Äôve been able to help local firms to get back on their feet. london.gov.uk/press-releases:=:https://www.london.gov.uk/media-centre‚Ä¶

Name: Sadiq Khan
Message: Today we came together today to remember the 71 lives so tragically lost in the Grenfell Tower fire six months ago ‚Äì the innocent victims young and old, children, parents, grandparents, friends and loved ones. Survivors are still grieving and traumatised, many will still be homeless this Christmas, and the community remains frustrated and angry ‚Äì and justifiably so. I share their anger and will continue to fight to ensure that they get justice as quickly as possible. Today is about remembering the many Londoners we lost that night. It is about the families and friends who miss them so desperately. And it is about a whole community that has been changed forever after that horrendous night. I am sure I speak for all Londoners when I say that our thoughts and prayers are with them. As Mayor, I have been granted Core Participant status in the Public Inquiry and I will not stop until I have done everything in my power to ensure that lessons are learned and nothing like the Grenfell...

Name: Sadiq Khan
Message: Today we come together to remember the 71 lives lost in the devastating Grenfell Tower fire six months ago. https://t.co/BHQnoVFyrZ:=:https://www.london.gov.uk/city-hall-blog/grenfell-tower-national-memorial-service

Name: Sadiq Khan
Message: 2017 has been a difficult year for our city - but Londoners‚Äô generosity and bravery has shone through. https://www.standard.co.uk/news/london/sadiq-khan-hails-incredible-generosity-and-bravery-of-londoners-after-extremely-difficult-2017-a3728901.html?amp#click=https://t.co/N8qu6DlJcF

Name: Sadiq Khan
Message: Today is #VisitMyMosqueDay, an illustration of how our city‚Äôs diversity is an asset to be unlocked, rather than a challenge to be managed - and that our Muslim communities, like London, are open and welcoming to all. A great example is Al Manaar Mosque in West London. The support they have given to survivors, their families & the local community following the horrific Grenfell Tower fire continues to demonstrate the true spirit of our city. Good to be back there again today.

Name: Sadiq Khan
Message: Whatever the legal position, it is morally wrong for leaseholders to be forced to pay substantial costs just to make their homes safe due to no fault of their own. It is particularly distressing that young families have been left worrying about the safety of their homes, seeing the value of their home slashed, and are being forced to put their lives on hold because of the blight caused by ongoing uncertainty. It is not acceptable for the Government to sit back and allow this to play out over the coming months or years, as people live with uncertainty and in many cases fear for their safety. Across the board, the Government must find a way to speed up the legal processes, to ensure that cladding cases are prioritised and heard by the tribunal or court at the earliest opportunity. Where there is significant delay, the Government must ensure the works are done immediately to make sure homes are safe....

Name: Sadiq Khan
Message: Today it‚Äôs been announced that a panel of experts will sit alongside a judge at the Grenfell Tower Inquiry. I have repeatedly called for this, and so welcome the Prime Minister finally agreeing to this. This is a very important and long-overdue concession from the Government ‚Äì and one that I and others have been calling for since the Public Inquiry was established. However, it is crucial that the diversity, background and experience of those appointed ensures the panel can effectively understand the issues being raised in the Inquiry. I want to pay tribute to the Grenfell families, survivors and the local community who fought so hard for this. If we are to get justice for the Grenfell victims and their families, it is absolutely vital that they have full confidence in the Inquiry. The Grenfell Tower fire shocked us all. As well as the heartache, it shone a light on the stark inequalities that still exist in our country - one of the richest countries in the world. It must...

Name: Sadiq Khan
Message: I welcome the government‚Äôs intention to fund the removal of dangerous cladding, something I and others have long called for. It really should not have taken nearly a full year for Ministers to get their act together and support councils and housing associations who have been in limbo for far too long, causing misery and uncertainty for tenants and leaseholders. Now the government has finally woken up and recognised the importance of this issue, I hope they will move much quicker to ensure all the private blocks affected are identified and that disputes over costs do not stop works from being carried out. http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-44141374

Name: Sajid Javid
Message: My thoughts are still very much with victims, their family and friends #GrenfellTower

Message: Still in shock over Grenfell. I have signed up to volunteer for the Grenfell Tower Relief effort. You can do the same here: https://thekandcfoundation.com

Name: Sharon Hodgson
Message: Last weekend, it was confirmed that cladding was being removed from flats here in Sunderland, following the testing of some of the cladding. The cladding was removed as a precaution and was completed by Sunday lunchtime. None of this cladding was within the Washington and Sunderland West constituency, however, I want to assure constituents that I am in regular communication with Gentoo about this and will continue to work with them on this matter. I know lots of constituents have written to me about this issue in a general sense or on more specific issues, and I will be responding to all of those concerns and points shortly. The tragedy at Grenfell Tower has sent shock waves through the country, but has also unveiled some serious failures to ensure people‚Äôs safety is paramount. I will work hard in Parliament to press the Government on these matters as I know this is something the people of Washington and Sunderland West care about deeply. That is why I will be voting for an...

Name: Sir Peter Bottomley
Message: On 6 June, I made my 75th blood donation, excluding platelet donations. Today a text message informed me that the gift had been issued to Charing Cross Hospital, London. I shall never know whether this gift of blood is of benefit to a person injured at Grenfell Tower or last night‚Äôs incident near Finsbury Park Mosque. I do know that if enough of us make regular donations, the #NHS will keep stocks high for ordinary needs and at times of extraordinary demand. Over 6,000 blood donations are required every day to treat patients in need across England. This is why there is always a need for people to give blood. Most people between the ages of 17-65 are able to donate. You can find out more about giving blood, and search for an appointment in Worthing or elsewhere, at www.blood.co.uk:=:https://www.blood.co.uk/ #GiveBlood NHS Blood Donation British Red Cross

Name: Sir Peter Bottomley
Message: Yesterday I spoke out in support of both leaseholders and tenants, calling on the Government to hasten the determination of liability for fire safety remedial work, ensuring that the Government, local authorities, and those involved can swiftly move forwards with making the necessary improvements to protect lives both in Worthing, West Sussex and across the country. This is an issue that is extremely important, especially following the atrocity of Grenfell Tower. You can watch a brief segment of my speech in Westminster Hall below, or follow this link to see my speech in its entirety, as well as the rest of the debate: https://www.theyworkforyou.com/whall/?id=2018-03-06a.76.0#g82.0

Name: Sir Peter Bottomley
Message: Yesterday, following a statement regarding the Grenfell Tower tragedy and subsequent measures to address dangerous cladding, I urged Sajid Javid, Secretary of State for Housing, Communities, and Local Government, to bring together key actors and stakeholders in order to finalise a deal and get the dangerous cladding removed and replaced with the upmost urgency. Please follow the below link to see both my recommendation to the Secretary of State and his response: https://goo.gl/j5N47c:=:http://parliamentlive.tv/event/index/dc0d8dcf-d477-4358-b463-7d32b191d3ca?in=11:50:45&out=11:52:42

Name: Sir Peter Bottomley
Message: Many leaseholders, not only in Worthing but across the country, are being left in danger due to a severe delay in removing unsafe cladding from buildings. During today's update regarding the Grenfell Tower tragedy, Sajid Javid, Secretary of State for Department for Housing, Communities, and Local Government, accepted my advice to bring together the most important and experienced actors and bodies to address the issue swiftly. The Secretary of State has the opportunity now to ensure that the safety of leaseholders across the country is addressed urgently and resolutely.

Name: Sir Peter Bottomley
Message: Earlier this week I welcomed the new Secretary of State for Housing, Communities, and Local Governments, James Brokenshire MP, and stressed the importance that he continue the work begun by his predecessor, Sajid Javid, had achieved in further fighting for the rights of leaseholders across the country. Following the tragedy of Grenfell Tower, it is more important than ever that we ensure dangerous cladding is removed post-haste, with the financial implications borne by those responsible for its use rather than those it was imposed on. The Secretary of States' response was highly receptive and signals that, as I would hope, he will continue to work alongside myself, my Parliamentary colleagues, and Leasehold Knowledge Partnership, in furthering the work to the protect endangered lives of leaseholders across this country.

Name: Sir Peter Bottomley
Message: Last week the All-Party Group on Leasehold and Commonhold Reform, to which I am Co-chair, held a highly successful meeting with over 80 attendees from within the leasehold sector including the legal profession and many of my colleagues from across Parliament. Speakers included John Hall, Director at the Ministry of Housing Communities and Local Government, who updated MPs and leasehold sector insiders on government action to outlaw leasehold houses and reduce ground rents to as low as zero. Law Commissioner Professor Nicholas Hopkins outlined progress on his review of leasehold enfranchisement and extension, and commonhold. After the meeting there was a drinks reception to celebrate the achievements of the Leasehold Knowledge Partnership, which is also the secretariat of the APPG, in finally getting leasehold reform onto the government‚Äôs agenda. We are making progress, none of which would have been possible without the hard work of many individuals and groups who are uniting for...

Name: Steve Double
Message: My column for the local papers this week, on the Grenfell Tower tragedy: 'As I head back up to Parliament this week for the Queen‚Äôs Speech and start of the next session of Parliament, the tragic events of the fire at Grenfell Tower last Wednesday are not far from any of our minds. This was a terrible tragedy and my thoughts and prayers are with all those affected, those who lost their lives and their families. Praise must be given to our emergency services for acting how they did, running into the flames when others were running away and putting their own lives on the line to save those in danger. The Prime Minister has promised a comprehensive package of support for victims of the Grenfell Tower tragedy. During a meeting with survivors of the fire, she announced a ¬£5 million fund would be made available to pay for emergency supplies, food, clothes and other costs. The package includes: a commitment that victims who lost their homes in the disaster must be rehoused at the earliest...

Name: Sue Hayman
Message: Today I've been in Westminster to give my backing for a Private Member‚Äôs Bill introduced by Labour MP Karen Buck, which would give renters a new legal right to ensure their home is ‚Äòfit for human habitation‚Äô. The new legislation, long campaigned for by Labour, could help renters in 162,000 dangerously unfit properties in the North West. Nationally, there are over one million rented properties containing the most serious ‚Äòcategory 1‚Äô hazards, including homes that have unsafe electrics, vermin infestations, or aren‚Äôt fire safe. The bill will give tenants new legal powers to enforce their right to a decent home by taking their landlord to court if the property they live in is not fit. This is a particularly important for council tenants such as those who lived in Grenfell Tower, because it is councils who are notionally responsible for enforcing standards, but local authorities can‚Äôt enforce against themselves. This change in the law was backed by Labour previously and was included in...

Name: Suella Braverman
Message: Today I visited Furze Court in response to residents' worries about the fire safety. Ever since the tragedy at Grenfell Tower, the government has been working closely with local authorities, housing associations and the private sector to ensure the safety of high-rise buildings. Furze Court is not high-rise but I am concerned that there may be safety risks within the flats and am taking action with the management company to properly assess the fire safety for residents. My special thanks to Cllr Sarah Pankhurst who alerted me to this issue and the residents who showed me round the estate. It is the responsibility of landlords and freeholders to advise their residents what to do in the event of a fire in the building, based on risk assessments carried out. I am aware that the tragic incident at Grenfell Tower and now the evacuation in Camden will be particularly worrying for those living in high-rise towers and in flats. However, fire safety standards are in place in buildings...

Name: teresa pearce
Message: Two Shelter board members quit after Grenfell Tower fire https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2017/jun/23/two-shelter-board-members-derek-myers-tony-rice-quit-after-grenfell-tower-fire?CMP=share_btn_tw

Message: Look at Grenfell Tower and see the terrible price of Britain‚Äôs inequality | Lynsey Hanley https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2017/jun/16/grenfell-tower-price-britain-inequality-high-rise?CMP=share_btn_tw

Message: My question to the PM today on the Grenfell Tower tragedy, and safety in all tower blocks (TD office) http://www.debbonaire.co.uk/question_to_the_prime_minister_on_grenfell_tower_statement via @ThangamMP

Name: The Labour Party
Message: As we returned to parliament today, Jeremy paid tribute to those who lost their lives in the fire at Grenfell Tower. All those who live in tower blocks across the country need urgent reassurance, and our emergency services deserve our deepest respect.

Name: The Labour Party
Message: Today in Prime Minister's Questions, Jeremy Corbyn‚Äã represented those affected by the tragedy at Grenfell Tower. This fire was a horrific and utterly avoidable tragedy, and it's vital that we learn the lessons and ensure that this can never happen again. This disaster must be a wake-up call. Share Jeremy's message to the Tories ‚Üì

Name: The Labour Party
Message: ‚ÄúThe Grenfell Tower fire was a national tragedy, exposing a national breakdown in our system of fire-safety checks and controls. It demands a national response from government to make sure it can never happen again.‚Äù Agree with John Healey MP? Sign our letter to Theresa May now ‚Üí labour.org.uk/makehomessafe:=:https://action.labour.org.uk/page/s/make-homes-safe/

Name: The Labour Party
Message: The Tories just asked Kensington residents to rate how important the Grenfell tragedy is on a scale of 0-10. Insensitive doesn't even cover it. So why don't you rate the Tories' compassion ‚Äì on a scale of 0-0. Sign this ‚Üì

Name: The Labour Party
Message: This is what the press had to say about the Tories‚Äô insensitive Grenfell survey. SPOILER: They weren‚Äôt impressed. If the Tories had listened to the victims of Grenfell, they wouldn‚Äôt have to ask. So let‚Äôs remind them what a national tragedy this was. Name: The Labour Party
Message: How can Theresa May stand up in PMQs and say she‚Äôs ‚Äòtaking Grenfell seriously‚Äô when her party just sent out a SURVEY asking local residents to rate the tragedy on a scale of 0-10? Appalled? Us too. Share and sign this ‚Üì http://bit.ly/mhs-lf:=:https://action.labour.org.uk/page/s/make-homes-safe/?source=makehomessafe&subsource=facebook&utm_medium=facebook&utm_source=facebookpost&utm_campaign=makehomessafe

Name: The Labour Party
Message: This week, we marked the six month anniversary of the tragedy at Grenfell tower. Here's Jeremy Corbyn's message ‚Üì

Name: The Labour Party
Message: The Tories can‚Äôt ignore this any longer. Theresa May must act now and allocate the funds needed to make homes safe from fire. Make sure a friend knows about this ‚Üì

Name: Theresa May
Message: ‚Ä™I am deeply saddened by the tragic loss of life at Grenfell Tower. My thoughts are with all those affected and the emergency services.‚Ä¨

Name: Theresa May
Message: I can confirm that emergency funding has been made available to assist with the response to the Grenfell Tower incident.

Name: Theresa May
Message: It is our job as a government to show we are listening and that we will stand up for the people of Grenfell Tower. And that is what I am determined we should do.

Name: Theresa May
Message: Six months on the Grenfell fire remains at the front of our minds as a truly unimaginable tragedy that should never have happened. Many who survived lost everything that night, my Government will continue to do all we can for them and learn the lessons so it never happens again.

Name: Theresa May
Message: As we gather with our friends and family, I want to say thank you to all those whose service to others means they will be spending time away from their loved ones this Christmas. Men and women in our armed forces whose humbling bravery and daily sacrifices help to ensure the security of our nation and our allies around the world. The heroes in our emergency services whose courage and dedication so inspired the nation in response to tragedy at Grenfell Tower and the abhorrent terrorist attacks in Manchester and London. But whose service saves lives in our communities every day, including Christmas Day. And the thousands of volunteers in our country who will give up their time to make someone else‚Äôs Christmas that little bit better: from faith inspired projects like the Churches Together initiative in my own constituency - to aid workers helping those in war-torn parts of the world. As we celebrate the birth of Christ, let us celebrate all those selfless acts - and countless others -...

Name: Theresa Villiers
Message: The Grenfell Tower disaster is truly shocking. I welcome the decision to set up a full public inquiry to establish what happened and ensure we do everything we can to prevent such a tragedy from ever occurring again. I agree with the Mayor of London that the inquiry should produce an interim report as soon as possible. I have been in touch with the Barnet Council to stress the importance of immediate action to establish whether any buildings in Barnet suffer from the same problems which appear to have played a part in the Grenfell fire. Whilst we cannot yet be certain of what the causes of the fire were, every effort should be made right away to make people as safe as possible in their homes, and Barnet Homes and Barnet Council are already taking action. I send my deepest condolences to all those families who have lost loved ones. My sympathies also go to victims who have been injured and to everyone who has lost their home.

Name: Theresa Villiers
Message: In Parliament this morning, MPs expressed their horror about the Grenfell fire and I had the chance to ask the Prime Minister a question. People living in high-rise buildings in Barnet will be worried about fire safety after these terrible events. I urged Barnet Council to take action and I welcome the work they are undertaking to re-examine fire safety in high-rise blocks to find out whether any of the problems which contributed to the Grenfell disaster are present in Barnet. The Council has also made a commitment to invest in new fire safety measures, taking advice from the Fire Brigade on what is needed, including sprinklers where necessary. I asked the Prime Minister a question urging other local authorities to do the same. It is important that the owners of privately-owned blocks also take action, particularly where cladding has taken place. I will be pressing them to do that.

Name: Theresa Villiers
Message: The Secretary of State for Housing made a statement in in Parliament this morning on the latest developments in the investigation of the Grenfell tragedy. I would like to reiterate my sympathy and support to all the survivors of that terrible event, and to everyone who lost friends or family. I appealed to the Secretary of State to ensure that fire safety standards are not compromised when high-rise office blocks in Barnet are converted into flats using permitted development rights, without the need for planning permission. He emphasised that all building and fire safety regulations apply in such cases, even in the absence of a planning decision process.

Name: Tim Loughton
Message: The fire at Grenfell Tower was horrific and the extent of personal tragedy which had affected so many families is appalling and heart-breaking. My thoughts and prayers go out to all those who are affected and it must be our number one priority to account for those who have lost their lives, look after the survivors and give them whatever support and comfort they need and get to the bottom of exactly what happened. I would particularly like to praise the heroic work carried out by the emergency services who reached the scene within minutes and risked their own lives to save the hundreds trapped in the building. As we know from the experience of the Shoreham Air Show tragedy the effect on those in uniform from whom we expect so much can be significant and long-lasting and need support. The response of the local community and countless volunteers from all walks of life was humbling and one of the few positive highlights of this tragedy. It is far too early to determine the cause of...

Name: Toby Perkins
Message: Whatever emerges about Grenfell, Govt have questions to answer on their record on protecting tenants. http://www.mirror.co.uk/news/politics/theresa-mays-chief-staff-sat-10620357#ICID=sharebar_twitter

Name: Tom Blenkinsop
Message: The cladding in question at #grenfell is also banned in the UK https://twitter.com/thesundaytimes/status/876341216652165120

Message: London fire: Lives claimed at Grenfell Tower http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-london-40269625

Name: Tom Blenkinsop
Message: Grenfell Tower: Government sends in 'taskforce' http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-40504145

Message: Grenfell cladding boss is a government adviser | News | The Times & The Sunday Times https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/26960232-5dcd-11e7-8b02-b735a4dd8be3

Name: Tom Brake
Message: My thoughts and prayers are with everyone affected by the fire at Grenfell Tower and our courageous emergency services.

Name: Tom Brake
Message: See below - a local drop off point for donations for those affected by the Grenfell Tower fire. Please spread the word.

Name: Tom Brake
Message: The type of cladding that was used on Grenfell Tower is not only classified as flammable material in Germany but also prohibited in US buildings that exceed 40 feet in height due to fire safety concerns. After many lives were lost in the Grenfell Tower fire, the Liberal Democrats have called for this dangerous material to be banned in the UK. The Times found that using fire-resistant panels would have cost merely ¬£5000 more than flammable ones. It is unacceptable that people died because fire safety was neglected. It is time we made the necessary investment to ensure that tragedies like these do not happen again and to guarantee people‚Äôs safety. Check the following for an update for the situation in Sutton: http://bit.ly/2tbXu0b:=:http://www.newsroomsutton.co.uk/archive/update-on-steps-by-sutton-council-and-partners-to-ensure-safety-in-high-rise-properties/

Name: Tom Brake
Message: Fire-resistant panels would have cost just ¬£5000 more than Grenfell Tower‚Äôs flammable ones. Deaths could have been prevented #unacceptable

Name: Tom Brake
Message: Very disappointed that PM did not agree, in response to my question earlier today, to ban the cladding used on Grenfell Tower.

Name: Tom Brake
Message: Incredible generosity from the Islamic community of Sutton‚Äôs Central Masjid, supported by the Muslim Cultural and the Welfare Association of Sutton and Epsom and Ewell Islamic Society, in raising ¬£3,000 for the victims of Grenfell Tower. Sutton‚Äôs Mayor, Councillor Jean Crossby, Councillor Trish Fivey and I will accept the cheque on October 4 before passing it on.

Name: Tom Brake
Message: Tragic but typical that govt. hasn‚Äôt addressed independent report demanding increase in safety of electrical goods. Even after #Grenfell.

Name: Tom Brake
Message: Govt. rejected their own independent report‚Äôs advice that electrical safety checks be made compulsory in rented homes, improving safety and saving lives. Even after Grenfell tragedy they won‚Äôt learn.

Name: Tom Brake
Message: A new interim report has shed light on the Grenfell tower tragedy. The report, looking into building safety regulations, has warned that the current system is ‚Äúnot fit for purpose‚Äù, due in part to weak enforcement of the rules and lack of clarity over who is responsible. Thousands of families across the country continue to live in unsafe accommodation. That is why I am calling on the government to take swift action. Proper enforcement of current regulations and additional funding for safety improvements are urgently required to prevent another disaster.

Name: Tom Brake
Message: Speaking during the #Grenfell Urgent Question earlier today I challenged the Govt on the need to act on the recall of faulty electrical products. Such an appliance started the tragic fire, yet only 20% of such products are recalled.

Name: Tom Pursglove
Message: Last Thursday, during a Statement on the awful events which happened at Grenfell Tower, I pointed out how the Prime Minister was absolutely right to highlight the incredible work of the brave firefighters who attended the scene in the immediate aftermath of the incident, and then asked if she would ensure not only that they are properly recognised for their herculean efforts, but also that any welfare needs that arise are met immediately. In her reply, the Prime Minister absolutely agreed with those comments. She added that support is being given to the firefighters, and indeed to the police and others who attended the scene, because they, too, could potentially suffer trauma as a result of what they have seen, so that comprehensive support will be available. You can see my question and the Prime Minister‚Äôs answer, here:...

Name: Tom Pursglove
Message: On Monday, during a Statement on the Grenfell Tower tragedy, I mentioned my meeting with the Leader and Chief Executive of Corby Borough Council last Friday, at which I was assured that the council has complied with all safety check requests the Department has made, in the aftermath of this awful tragedy. Indeed, I shall ask the same of East Northamptonshire Council at a scheduled meeting I have with them tomorrow. I then asked the Secretary of State for Communities and Local Government if there was anything more that individual MPs could do to support Ministers and the Government with engagement, working across party lines and with local authorities, during the important review process that lay ahead. In his response, the Secretary of State mentioned the importance of informing constituents on the testing process and what the results mean. Rest assured that I will continue to keep a close eye on this process - any lessons emerging from this tragedy must be acted upon...

Name: Tom Pursglove
Message: Last Friday, after undertaking home visits to constituents, I had one of my regular catch-up meetings with David Oliver, the Chief Executive of East Northamptonshire Council, and Councillor Steven North, the Leader of the Council, in order to update each other, and to discuss the most pressing local issues. This was a productive meeting, and it was good to catch up and hear about the latest developments on key projects in East Northamptonshire and particularly, to discuss progress at Rushden Lakes. As I did a fortnight before in Corby, I was also able to ask if the local authority had complied with all of the requests made of them by the Government, following the tragic fire at Grenfell Tower, and I am reassured to be able to report that they have done so.

Name: Tom Pursglove
Message: Last Thursday, during a Statement about Grenfell Tower and fire safety, I said that I understood from previous answers from Ministers that local authorities have been very good at meeting the different safety requests that the Government have made of them in light of this tragedy, and I then further asked if any specific pressure could be applied to non-compliant housing associations by individual councils ‚Äì as we simply cannot take any chances with safety in their housing stock. In his response, the Secretary of State acknowledged that local authorities have generally been good in their response, and of the buildings that have had their cladding tested or proxy tested, 46 are local authority buildings. He added that local authorities have certainly been very helpful, and that this will be looked at further in terms of them helping to apply pressure on housing associations in specific areas. You can see my question and the Secretary of State‚Äôs answer, here:...

Name: Tom Pursglove
Message: On Monday, during a Statement on the ongoing response to June‚Äôs tragic fire at Grenfell Tower and the wider review of building safety, I pointed out how the Secretary of State had previously said that the local authority had accepted the recommendations of the independent taskforce in full, and I asked if he would update the House about progress on implementing those recommendations. In his response, the Secretary of State outlined how he meets with the local council regularly and how he also has discussions with the taskforce. He added that a number of points were set out in the taskforce report, and the local authority has set up a group to go through each in detail. He also assured me that as we get further details, he will bring them to the House. The lessons of this tragedy must be learnt, as this can never be allowed to happen again - and, particularly at this time of year, we pause to think of all those affected by this dreadful tragedy. You can see my question and the...

Name: Tom Pursglove
Message: Last Tuesday, I went to a drop-in session at Speaker‚Äôs House organised by Grenfell United. This was a very useful opportunity to get an update on the current situation, but also to meet and talk to survivors about their individual experiences, particularly given the parliamentary debate which is to take place next week. The conversations were extremely difficult and very, very, moving, but an important opportunity for us as MPs to get the direct feedback of those so tragically affected, and make sure we are doing everything we possibly can to help them rebuild their lives and ensure a tragedy like this can never happen again. Photography by Marley Edwards.

Name: Tom Tugendhat
Message: Tonight many Muslims in London will be preparing for iftar, the meal that breaks the Ramadan fast. Traditionally it is a time for celebration when family and friends gather. After mosques and churches have been collecting for those lost everything in the Grenfell Tower it will be more muted. The death of Mohammed al-Haj Ali who fled the war in Syria and the loss of the el-Wahabi family, the final calls home from Marco Gottardi and his girlfriend Gloria Trevisan, both architects from the Veneto region of northern Italy, will be in the minds of many. This tragedy has exposed failings in our society. Not one that affects only the poor or only the rich, but all of us. We are all hurt by this tragedy and must find out what happened and stop it ever happening again. It's also why we must open criminal proceedings and be ready to prosecute those whose failings led to this terrible fire. I have written to the housing providers in Tonbridge and Malling to make sure they have taken all the...

Name: Tom Watson
Message: "Unless people have the skills and support to make themselves heard in the corridors of power, disasters such as the Grenfell Tower fire will continue to happen" - I couldn't agree more: https://www.theguardian.com/voluntary-sector-network/2017/aug/09/communities-charities-campaigning-politics-democracy?CMP=Share_iOSApp_Other

Name: Tom Watson
Message: It is vital that the Government makes the money available to fit sprinklers into high-rise social housing. The tragedy of Grenfell Tower must never be repeated. Please sign Jeremy Corbyn's letter to Theresa May, urging her to set aside the funds to install sprinklers and make homes safe for thousands of families. Stand with us ‚Äì add your signature to our letter now ‚Üì http://bit.ly/mhs-lf:=:https://action.labour.org.uk/page/s/make-homes-safe/?source=makehomessafe&subsource=facebook&utm_medium=facebook&utm_source=facebookpost&utm_campaign=makehomessafe

Name: Tom Watson
Message: The tragedy of Grenfell Tower was a national disgrace and the way it was handled by Kensington and Chelsea council - both in the aftermath and still today - is also a national disgrace. I welcome the intervention by the Equalities and Human Rights Commission to launch a swift inquiry into whether the government and the council failed in their duties to protect life and provide safe housing. Most importantly, they will report back in April. That's four months time, not four years down the line. The victims, the survivors and the families deserve answers and they deserve them quickly.

Name: Tom Watson
Message: Today is six months on from Grenfell. It must not happen again.

Name: Tom Watson
Message: Residents of a tower block clad with the same flammable material as Grenfell are terrified. Five months ago, under pressure from local Labour MP Steve Reed, the government told the freeholder to remove the cladding. But the wealthy landlords have refused until each leaseholder hands over ¬£31,300 to carry out the ¬£2m work - money which few, if any, have. Steve, my shadow ministerial colleague, says: ‚ÄúIt is an absolute outrage to leave people in a building which they know isn‚Äôt safe and is at risk of burning down like Grenfell Tower did. ‚ÄúTheir homes are becoming worthless and they are living in fear of their lives. Grenfell Tower is still there in the centre of London, a smouldering wreck, and these people think they could be next.‚Äù P.S. The family who own the freehold, via their property company, are said to be worth ¬£850m.

Name: Tom Watson
Message: When Stormzy called out Theresa May on Grenfell and lambasted The Daily Mail on live TV, it gave me real hope - that the rich men who own and control our right wing newspapers can't control the message any more. This man speaks for a generation who won't take the lies and smears any longer. And last night at the Brits he truly stole the show with his stellar performance. Great album, great man, great message.

Name: Tom Watson
Message: Footballers and football clubs often get a bad press. But what Les Ferdinand and QPR have contributed to the local community in the aftermath of Grenfell deserves real praise. It started in the immediacy of the tragedy with Loftus Road becoming a centre for food, blankets and donations; then came Game4Grenfell - the charity match that raised half a million pounds. Now there's on-going football training for the children, psychological support for survivors and a long-term pledge to support the community. Reflecting on the 152 families still without housing, Les, who grew up on the estate, says: "It‚Äôs ridiculous to think that these people who lost loved ones, lost friends, are still holed up in hotels. ‚ÄúPeople do a lot of talking about what‚Äôs right and what‚Äôs wrong but it‚Äôs the actions that count. And we‚Äôve not done enough.‚Äù We can never do enough. But Les, you and your club are doing the right thing. Thank you.

Name: Tom Watson
Message: ‚ÄúLabour says ministers made false claims about cladding after Grenfell‚Äù https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2018/mar/07/labour-says-ministers-made-false-claims-about-cladding-after-grenfell?CMP=Share_iOSApp_Other

Name: Tom Watson
Message: "There was an Afghan army officer, a Sudanese dressmaker, a British artist and an Italian architect. There was an Egyptian hairdresser, an Eritrean waitress and a Lebanese soldier..." A perfect intro to the Guardian's hugely significant front page today on the victims of Grenfell. As MPs debate the catastrophe, the public inquiry opens next week and the June 14 anniversary approaches, it is vital we shout the names of the Grenfell 71 loud and clear.

Name: Tom Watson
Message: Edward Daffarn predicted Grenfell. He predicted it in the blogs he wrote in the two years before the fire of June 14th 2017. We all read them afterwards, when it was too late, when 72 people were killed and hundreds of lives changed forever. Edward's first newspaper interview should be read by everyone. But most of all by politicians and public servants, who must vow that the voices of people like Edward Daffarn will never be ignored again.

Name: Tommy Sheppard
Message: I think we are all still processing the appalling news of the horrific fire at Grenfell House in London and the terrible loss of life ‚Äì the extent of which is still becoming clear. My thoughts are with everyone affected and their families. The public inquiry into what has gone wrong promised by the UK Government must be thorough and wide-ranging. Upon hearing the news, I immediately contacted the City of Edinburgh Council to seek assurances about the fire safety of residents of multi-storey tower blocks in Edinburgh East and across the city more generally. The Council has responded with the following statement: ‚ÄúWe are deeply saddened by this morning‚Äôs tragic incident in London and our thoughts and prayers are with all those affected. Understandably the events in London this morning have caused concern and some distress and our local housing teams have been on hand today to provide reassurance and advice to tenants living in city tower blocks. ‚ÄúRegular inspections are carried out...

Name: Tommy Sheppard
Message: My week started with a 9am briefing this morning from senior council and fire service officials. Since the tragedy happened at Grenfell House in West London they have been looking at fire safety in Edinburgh's high rise blocks. Everyone is anxious to make sure that such a horrific tragedy cannot happen again. There are 45 multi-storey blocks of flats in Edinburgh - housing about 4000 tenants. Of these, 16 are relatively modern and have not been refurbished. The remaining 29 have had works done including external cladding. Every single one of them was inspected last week and we were told that in no case were materials used which were the same as those in Grenfell. All the cladding and insulation panels are mineral based and non-combustible. I asked for a brief specific report on each individual block outlining construction method and material, fire safety procedures and recommendations for improvement. I will make this available on my website when I have it. Officials are confident...

Name: Tommy Sheppard
Message: Yesterday I spoke in the Westminster Hall debate on Grenfell (link to my speech below). Following the debate where there was serious cross party concern about how the local council has dealt with this matter the debate moves to the main chamber tomorrow. Let's hope the Government can come up with some better answers now they've had some time to think about it. https://youtu.be/H2kN77hRPEk:=:https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=H2kN77hRPEk&feature=youtu.be

Message: Yesterday I spoke in the debate on Grenfell Tower - we need the fullest possible inquiry and one that has the confidence of those who were most affected by the disaster.

Message: I have spoken to Gedling Homes about all of their properties in light of the tragic Grenfell Tower fire in London. They are reviewing any planned refurbishment works including the refurbishment of Walton Court in Carlton. The cladding work is on hold until a review is carried out. http://www.nottinghampost.com/carlton-tower-block-cladding-work-on-hold-after-grenfell-tower-fire-in-london/story-30392432-detail/story.html

Message: Councils like #Lewisham are implementing safety measures to ensure blocks are safe after #Grenfell. 4 months on - still no funding from Gov. https://t.co/NgUNGx0ITS

Name: Victoria Atkins
Message: There have been two terrible events in London during the last week. The first was the horrific fire at Grenfell Tower and last night a hateful terror attack was committed near a north London mosque. Yet again, the emergency services have acted with extraordinary courage and fortitude, and local residents have rallied round with great kindness and bravery. My thoughts and prayers are with everyone affected.

Message: Thank you to @Al_Hasaniya for hosting discussion with local residents about Grenfell tragedy #VictoriaBorwick https://t.co/tziDkReHgC

Message: Notting Hill carnival is unsafe. But, like Grenfell, authorities ignore the warnings | Lee Jasper https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2017/aug/25/grenfell-warnings-notting-hill-carnival-safety-ignored?CMP=share_btn_tw Good history

Message: Here is an important update from Redbridge Council regarding fire safety at tower blocks in our community. Name: Wes Streeting
Message: Earlier this week The APPG on British Muslims was pleased to produce a report on the contribution made by Muslim charities to those in need at this time of the year. Many people will be quietly helping the homeless, assisting with food collections or offering a hot meal. Anna Soubry MP and I wanted to not only highlight this important work, which doesn't always get the credit it deserves, but also show that we have so much in common ‚Äì a shared humanity ‚Äì regardless of our faith or background. We've written about some of these quiet acts of kindness in the article below. If you can, do consider helping those less fortunate during these colder months. #AVeryMerryMuslimChristmas

Name: Wes Streeting
Message: Finally, here's a Muslim choir singing in St Paul's Cathedral at the Grenfell Memorial. Isn't our country great? #MoreinCommon https://t.co/zPAGlUT5YY

Name: Yvette Cooper
Message: Following the Grenfell tower fire, I'm very concerned that there still hasn't been proper testing of insulation in other high rise blocks, which the police investigating the fire have said was "more flammable than cladding". I've raised this repeatedly with ministers and I don't understand why they aren't testing insulation in the same way as they are testing cladding. People have a right to feel safe in their homes and Government has a responsibility to act to make sure serious fire risks are addressed.
